title: .NET Core
content:
Free and open-source software platform developed by Microsoft

**.NET Core** is a [free and open-source](/wiki/Free_and_open-source "Free and open-source"), [managed](/wiki/Managed_code "Managed code") computer [software framework](/wiki/Software_framework "Software framework") for [Windows](/wiki/Microsoft_Windows "Microsoft Windows"), [Linux](/wiki/Linux "Linux"), and [macOS](/wiki/MacOS "MacOS") [operating systems](/wiki/Operating_system "Operating system").[[4]](#cite_note-4) It is a cross-platform[[5]](#cite_note-5) successor to [.NET Framework](/wiki/.NET_Framework ".NET Framework").[[6]](#cite_note-6) The project is primarily developed by [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft") employees by way of the [.NET Foundation](/wiki/.NET_Foundation ".NET Foundation"), and released under the [MIT License](/wiki/MIT_License "MIT License").[[3]](#cite_note-GHlicense-3)





## Contents



*   [1 History](#History)
*   [2 Language support](#Language_support)
*   [3 Architecture](#Architecture)
*   [4 Notes](#Notes)
*   [5 References](#References)
*   [6 External links](#External_links)



## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=.NET_Core&action=edit§ion=1 "Edit section: History")]

.NET Core 1.0, announced on November 12, 2014,[[7]](#cite_note-7) was released on June 27, 2016,[[8]](#cite_note-arstechnicanetcorereleased-8) along with [Microsoft Visual Studio](/wiki/Microsoft_Visual_Studio "Microsoft Visual Studio") 2015 Update 3, which enables .NET Core development.[[9]](#cite_note-9) .NET Core 1.0.4 and .NET Core 1.1.1 were released along with .NET Core Tools 1.0 and Visual Studio 2017 on March 7, 2017.[[10]](#cite_note-10)

.NET Core 2.0 was released on August 14, 2017, along with Visual Studio 2017 15.3, ASP.NET Core 2.0, and [Entity Framework](/wiki/Entity_Framework "Entity Framework") Core 2.0.[[11]](#cite_note-:0-11) .NET Core 2.1 was released on May 30, 2018.[[12]](#cite_note-:1-12) NET Core 2.2 was released on December 4, 2018.[[13]](#cite_note-:2-13)

.NET Core 3 was announced on May 7, 2019, at Microsoft Build. Version 3.0.0 was released on September 23, 2019.[[14]](#cite_note-14) With .NET Core 3, the framework supports development of desktop [application software](/wiki/Application_software "Application software"), [artificial intelligence](/wiki/Artificial_intelligence "Artificial intelligence")/[machine learning](/wiki/Machine_learning "Machine learning") and [IoT](/wiki/Internet_of_things "Internet of things") apps.[[15]](#cite_note-15)[_[failed verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")_]

The next release after .NET Core 3.1 will be .NET 5\. The [.NET Framework](/wiki/.NET_Framework ".NET Framework") will not receive any further major versions, and .NET 5 will be the only .NET meant for new applications going forward – hence the removal of the "Core" branding and skipping of version 4 to avoid confusion with the .NET Framework 4.x.[[16]](#cite_note-:3-16) The first preview of .NET 5 was released on March 16, 2020.[[17]](#cite_note-17)

.NET Core 2.1 and later, i.e. including .NET 5, supports [Alpine Linux](/wiki/Alpine_Linux "Alpine Linux") (i.e. [musl](/wiki/Musl "Musl") libc it uses[[24]](#cite_note-24)).[[25]](#cite_note-25)

## Language support[[edit](/w/index.php?title=.NET_Core&action=edit§ion=2 "Edit section: Language support")]



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Dotnet-bot.svg/220px-Dotnet-bot.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Dotnet-bot.svg)



[](/wiki/File:Dotnet-bot.svg "Enlarge")

dotnet-bot, the community mascot for .NET





.NET Core fully supports [C#](/wiki/C_Sharp_(programming_language) "C Sharp (programming language)") and [F#](/wiki/F_Sharp_(programming_language) "F Sharp (programming language)") (and [C++/CLI](/wiki/C%2B%2B/CLI "C++/CLI") as of 3.1; only enabled on Windows) and supports [Visual Basic .NET](/wiki/Visual_Basic_.NET "Visual Basic .NET") (for version 15.5 in .NET Core 5.0.100-preview.4, and some old versions supported in old .NET Core).

VB.NET compiles and runs on .NET Core, but as of .NET Core 3.1, the separate Visual Basic Runtime is not implemented. Microsoft initially announced that .NET Core 3 would include the Visual Basic Runtime, but after two years the timeline for such support was updated to .NET 5.[[26]](#cite_note-26)[[27]](#cite_note-27)

## Architecture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=.NET_Core&action=edit§ion=3 "Edit section: Architecture")]

.NET Core supports four [cross-platform](/wiki/Cross-platform "Cross-platform") scenarios: [ASP.NET Core](/wiki/ASP.NET_Core "ASP.NET Core") [web apps](/wiki/Web_app "Web app"); command-line apps; libraries; and [Universal Windows Platform apps](/wiki/Universal_Windows_Platform_apps "Universal Windows Platform apps"). Prior to .NET Core 3.0, it did not implement [Windows Forms](/wiki/Windows_Forms "Windows Forms") or [Windows Presentation Foundation](/wiki/Windows_Presentation_Foundation "Windows Presentation Foundation") (WPF), which render the standard [GUI](/wiki/GUI "GUI") for desktop software on Windows.[[28]](#cite_note-Cater2016-28)[[29]](#cite_note-Schmelzer_on_.NET_2015-29) Now, however, .NET Core 3 supports desktop technologies Windows Forms, WPF, and [Universal Windows Platform](/wiki/Universal_Windows_Platform "Universal Windows Platform") (UWP).[[30]](#cite_note-Lander2018-30)

.NET Core supports use of [NuGet](/wiki/NuGet "NuGet") packages. Unlike [.NET Framework](/wiki/.NET_Framework ".NET Framework"), which is serviced using [Windows Update](/wiki/Windows_Update "Windows Update"), .NET Core relies on its [package manager](/wiki/Package_manager "Package manager") to receive updates.[[28]](#cite_note-Cater2016-28)[[29]](#cite_note-Schmelzer_on_.NET_2015-29)

The two main components of .NET Core are CoreCLR and CoreFX, respectively, which are comparable to the [Common Language Runtime](/wiki/Common_Language_Runtime "Common Language Runtime") (CLR) and the [Framework Class Library](/wiki/Framework_Class_Library "Framework Class Library") (FCL) of the [.NET Framework](/wiki/.NET_Framework ".NET Framework")'s [Common Language Infrastructure](/wiki/Common_Language_Infrastructure "Common Language Infrastructure") (CLI) implementation.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

As a CLI implementation of [Virtual Execution System](/wiki/Virtual_Execution_System "Virtual Execution System") (VES), CoreCLR is a complete [runtime](/wiki/Runtime_system "Runtime system") and [virtual machine](/wiki/Virtual_machine "Virtual machine") for [managed](/wiki/Managed_code "Managed code") [execution](/wiki/Execution_(computing) "Execution (computing)") of .NET programs and includes a [just-in-time compiler](/wiki/Just-in-time_compiler "Just-in-time compiler") called RyuJIT.[[31]](#cite_note-31)[[a]](#cite_note-33) .NET Core also contains CoreRT, the .NET Native runtime optimized to be integrated into [AOT](/wiki/Ahead-of-time_compilation "Ahead-of-time compilation") compiled native [binaries](/wiki/Executable "Executable").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

As a CLI implementation of the foundational [Standard Libraries](/wiki/Standard_Libraries_(CLI) "Standard Libraries (CLI)"),[[33]](#cite_note-34) CoreFX shares a subset of .NET Framework APIs, however, it also comes with its own APIs that are not part of the .NET Framework.[[28]](#cite_note-Cater2016-28) A variant of the .NET Core [library](/wiki/Library_(computing) "Library (computing)") is used for [UWP](/wiki/Universal_Windows_Platform "Universal Windows Platform").[[34]](#cite_note-35)

The .NET Core [command-line interface](/wiki/Command-line_interface "Command-line interface") offers an execution entry point for [operating systems](/wiki/Operating_system "Operating system") and provides developer services like compilation and package management.[[35]](#cite_note-36)

## Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=.NET_Core&action=edit§ion=4 "Edit section: Notes")]





1.  **[^](#cite_ref-33 "Jump up")** The prefix "Ryu" is the Japanese word for "dragon" (竜, _ryū_), and is a reference to the book _[Compilers: Principles, Techniques, and Tools](/wiki/Compilers:_Principles,_Techniques,_and_Tools "Compilers: Principles, Techniques, and Tools")_ (commonly known as the dragon book, from an early cover design), as well as to a character from the video game _[Street Fighter](/wiki/Street_Fighter "Street Fighter")_.[[32]](#cite_note-32)

description: .NET Core is a free and open-source managed computer software framework.

title: Internet
content:
Global system of connected computer networks

This article is about the worldwide computer network. For the global system of pages accessed via URLs, see [World Wide Web](/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web").







Internet





[![Visualization of Internet routing paths](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Internet_map_1024_-_transparent%2C_inverted.png/150px-Internet_map_1024_-_transparent%2C_inverted.png)](/wiki/File:Internet_map_1024_-_transparent,_inverted.png "Visualization of Internet routing paths")

An [Opte Project](/wiki/Opte_Project "Opte Project") visualization of [routing paths](/wiki/Routing "Routing") through a portion of the Internet






[![A scatter plot showing internet usage per capita versus GDP per capita. It shows internet usage increasing with GDP.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Internet_users_for_100_people_by_GDP_per_capita.svg/220px-Internet_users_for_100_people_by_GDP_per_capita.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Internet_users_for_100_people_by_GDP_per_capita.svg)



[](/wiki/File:Internet_users_for_100_people_by_GDP_per_capita.svg "Enlarge")

Internet users per 100 population members and [GDP](/wiki/GDP "GDP") per capita for selected countries.





The **Internet** (or **[internet](/wiki/Capitalization_of_Internet "Capitalization of Internet")**) is the global system of interconnected [computer networks](/wiki/Computer_network "Computer network") that uses the [Internet protocol suite](/wiki/Internet_protocol_suite "Internet protocol suite") (TCP/IP) to communicate between networks and devices. It is a _network of networks_ that consists of private, public, academic, business, and government networks of local to global scope, linked by a broad array of electronic, wireless, and optical networking technologies. The Internet carries a vast range of information resources and services, such as the inter-linked [hypertext](/wiki/Hypertext "Hypertext") documents and [applications](/wiki/Web_application "Web application") of the [World Wide Web](/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web") (WWW), [electronic mail](/wiki/Email "Email"), [telephony](/wiki/Voice_over_IP "Voice over IP"), and [file sharing](/wiki/File_sharing "File sharing").

The origins of the Internet date back to the development of [packet switching](/wiki/Packet_switching "Packet switching") and research commissioned by the [United States Department of Defense](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense "United States Department of Defense") in the 1960s to enable [time-sharing](/wiki/Time-sharing "Time-sharing") of computers.[[1]](#cite_note-:4-1) The primary precursor network, the [ARPANET](/wiki/ARPANET "ARPANET"), initially served as a backbone for interconnection of regional academic and military networks in the 1970s. The funding of the [National Science Foundation Network](/wiki/National_Science_Foundation_Network "National Science Foundation Network") as a new backbone in the 1980s, as well as private funding for other commercial extensions, led to worldwide participation in the development of new networking technologies, and the merger of many networks.[[2]](#cite_note-2) The linking of commercial networks and enterprises by the early 1990s marked the beginning of the transition to the modern Internet,[[3]](#cite_note-3) and generated a sustained exponential growth as generations of institutional, [personal](/wiki/Personal_computer "Personal computer"), and [mobile](/wiki/Mobile_device "Mobile device") [computers](/wiki/Computer "Computer") were connected to the network. Although the Internet was widely used by [academia](/wiki/Academia "Academia") in the 1980s, [commercialization](/wiki/Commercialization_of_the_Internet "Commercialization of the Internet") incorporated its services and technologies into virtually every aspect of modern life.

Most traditional communication media, including telephony, radio, television, paper mail and newspapers are reshaped, redefined, or even bypassed by the Internet, giving birth to new services such as [email](/wiki/Email "Email"), [Internet telephony](/wiki/Internet_telephony "Internet telephony"), [Internet television](/wiki/Internet_television "Internet television"), [online music](/wiki/Online_music "Online music"), digital newspapers, and [video streaming](/wiki/Video_streaming "Video streaming") websites. Newspaper, book, and other print publishing are adapting to [website](/wiki/Web_site "Web site") technology, or are reshaped into [blogging](/wiki/Blogging "Blogging"), [web feeds](/wiki/Web_feed "Web feed") and online [news aggregators](/wiki/News_aggregator "News aggregator"). The Internet has enabled and accelerated new forms of personal interactions through [instant messaging](/wiki/Instant_messaging "Instant messaging"), [Internet forums](/wiki/Internet_forum "Internet forum"), and [social networking services](/wiki/Social_networking_service "Social networking service"). [Online shopping](/wiki/Online_shopping "Online shopping") has grown exponentially for major retailers, [small businesses](/wiki/Small_business "Small business"), and [entrepreneurs](/wiki/Entrepreneur "Entrepreneur"), as it enables firms to extend their "[brick and mortar](/wiki/Brick_and_mortar "Brick and mortar")" presence to serve a larger market or even [sell goods and services entirely online](/wiki/Online_store "Online store"). [Business-to-business](/wiki/Business-to-business "Business-to-business") and [financial services](/wiki/Financial_services "Financial services") on the Internet affect [supply chains](/wiki/Supply_chain "Supply chain") across entire industries.

The Internet has no single centralized governance in either technological implementation or policies for access and usage; each constituent network sets its own policies.[[4]](#cite_note-4) The overreaching definitions of the two principal [name spaces](/wiki/Name_space "Name space") in the Internet, the [Internet Protocol address](/wiki/IP_address "IP address") (IP address) space and the [Domain Name System](/wiki/Domain_Name_System "Domain Name System") (DNS), are directed by a maintainer organization, the [Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers](/wiki/Internet_Corporation_for_Assigned_Names_and_Numbers "Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers") (ICANN). The technical underpinning and standardization of the core protocols is an activity of the [Internet Engineering Task Force](/wiki/Internet_Engineering_Task_Force "Internet Engineering Task Force") (IETF), a non-profit organization of loosely affiliated international participants that anyone may associate with by contributing technical expertise.[[5]](#cite_note-5) In November 2006, the Internet was included on _[USA Today](/wiki/USA_Today "USA Today")'_s list of _[New Seven Wonders](/wiki/Wonders_of_the_World#USA_Today's_New_Seven_Wonders "Wonders of the World")_.[[6]](#cite_note-6)

## Terminology



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/PikiWiki_Israel_32304_The_Internet_Messenger_by_Buky_Schwartz.JPG/220px-PikiWiki_Israel_32304_The_Internet_Messenger_by_Buky_Schwartz.JPG)](/wiki/File:PikiWiki_Israel_32304_The_Internet_Messenger_by_Buky_Schwartz.JPG)



[](/wiki/File:PikiWiki_Israel_32304_The_Internet_Messenger_by_Buky_Schwartz.JPG "Enlarge")

_The Internet Messenger_ by [Buky Schwartz](/wiki/Buky_Schwartz "Buky Schwartz"), located in [Holon](/wiki/Holon "Holon"), [Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel")





Further information: [Capitalization of "Internet"](/wiki/Capitalization_of_%22Internet%22 "Capitalization of "Internet"")

The word _internetted_ was used as early as 1849, meaning _interconnected_ or _interwoven_.[[7]](#cite_note-7) Today, the term _Internet_ most commonly refers to the global system of interconnected [computer networks](/wiki/Computer_network "Computer network"), though it may also refer to any group of smaller networks. When it came into common use, most publications treated the word as a capitalized [proper noun](/wiki/Proper_noun_and_common_noun "Proper noun and common noun"); this has become less common.[[8]](#cite_note-:02-8) This reflects the tendency in English to capitalize new terms and move to lowercase as they become familiar.[[8]](#cite_note-:02-8)[[9]](#cite_note-:12-9) It is sometimes still capitalized to distinguish the global internet from smaller networks, though many publications, including the _[AP Stylebook](/wiki/AP_Stylebook "AP Stylebook")_, recommend the lowercase form in every case.[[8]](#cite_note-:02-8)[[9]](#cite_note-:12-9) In 2016, the _[Oxford English Dictionary](/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary "Oxford English Dictionary")_ found that, based on a study of around 2.5 billion printed and online sources, "Internet" was capitalized in 54% of cases.[[10]](#cite_note-10)

The terms _internet_ and _World Wide Web_ are often used interchangeably; it is common to speak of "_going on the Internet_" when using a [web browser](/wiki/Web_browser "Web browser") to view [web pages](/wiki/Web_page "Web page"). However, the [World Wide Web](/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web") or _the Web_ is only one of a large number of Internet services,[[11]](#cite_note-11) a collection of documents (web pages) and other [web resources](/wiki/Web_resource "Web resource"), linked by [hyperlinks](/wiki/Hyperlink "Hyperlink") and [URLs](/wiki/Uniform_resource_locator "Uniform resource locator").[[12]](#cite_note-12)

## History

Main articles: [History of the Internet](/wiki/History_of_the_Internet "History of the Internet") and [History of the World Wide Web](/wiki/History_of_the_World_Wide_Web "History of the World Wide Web")

In the 1960s, the [Advanced Research Projects Agency](/wiki/Advanced_Research_Projects_Agency "Advanced Research Projects Agency") (ARPA) of the [United States Department of Defense](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense "United States Department of Defense") funded research into [time-sharing](/wiki/Time-sharing "Time-sharing") of computers.[[13]](#cite_note-13)[[14]](#cite_note-14)[[15]](#cite_note-:2-15) Research into [packet switching](/wiki/Packet_switching "Packet switching"), one of the fundamental Internet technologies, started in the work of [Paul Baran](/wiki/Paul_Baran "Paul Baran") in the early 1960s and, independently, [Donald Davies](/wiki/Donald_Davies "Donald Davies") in 1965.[[1]](#cite_note-:4-1)[[16]](#cite_note-NIHF2007-16) After the [Symposium on Operating Systems Principles](/wiki/Symposium_on_Operating_Systems_Principles "Symposium on Operating Systems Principles") in 1967, packet switching from the proposed [NPL network](/wiki/NPL_network "NPL network") was incorporated into the design for the [ARPANET](/wiki/ARPANET "ARPANET") and other [resource sharing](/wiki/Resource_sharing "Resource sharing") networks such as the [Merit Network](/wiki/Merit_Network "Merit Network") and [CYCLADES](/wiki/CYCLADES "CYCLADES"), which were developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s.[[17]](#cite_note-17)

ARPANET development began with two network nodes which were interconnected between the Network Measurement Center at the [University of California, Los Angeles](/wiki/University_of_California,_Los_Angeles "University of California, Los Angeles") (UCLA) [Henry Samueli School of Engineering and Applied Science](/wiki/Henry_Samueli_School_of_Engineering_and_Applied_Science "Henry Samueli School of Engineering and Applied Science") directed by [Leonard Kleinrock](/wiki/Leonard_Kleinrock "Leonard Kleinrock"), and the NLS system at [SRI International](/wiki/SRI_International "SRI International") (SRI) by [Douglas Engelbart](/wiki/Douglas_Engelbart "Douglas Engelbart") in [Menlo Park](/wiki/Menlo_Park,_California "Menlo Park, California"), California, on 29 October 1969.[[18]](#cite_note-NetValley-18) The third site was the Culler-Fried Interactive Mathematics Center at the [University of California, Santa Barbara](/wiki/University_of_California,_Santa_Barbara "University of California, Santa Barbara"), followed by the [University of Utah](/wiki/University_of_Utah "University of Utah") Graphics Department. In a sign of future growth, 15 sites were connected to the young ARPANET by the end of 1971.[[19]](#cite_note-19)[[20]](#cite_note-20) These early years were documented in the 1972 film _[Computer Networks: The Heralds of Resource Sharing](/wiki/Computer_Networks:_The_Heralds_of_Resource_Sharing "Computer Networks: The Heralds of Resource Sharing")_.[[21]](#cite_note-21)

Early international collaborations for the ARPANET were rare. Connections were made in 1973 to the Norwegian Seismic Array ([NORSAR](/wiki/NORSAR "NORSAR")) via a satellite station in [Tanum](/wiki/Tanum_Municipality "Tanum Municipality"), Sweden, and to [Peter Kirstein](/wiki/Peter_T._Kirstein "Peter T. Kirstein")'s research group at [University College London](/wiki/University_College_London "University College London") which provided a gateway to British academic networks.[[22]](#cite_note-22)[[23]](#cite_note-23) The ARPA projects and [international working groups](/wiki/International_Networking_Working_Group "International Networking Working Group") led to the development of various [protocols](/wiki/Communication_protocol "Communication protocol") and standards by which multiple separate networks could become a single network or "a network of networks".[[24]](#cite_note-24) In 1974, [Vint Cerf](/wiki/Vint_Cerf "Vint Cerf") and [Bob Kahn](/wiki/Bob_Kahn "Bob Kahn") used the term _internet_ as a shorthand for Access to the ARPANET was expanded in 1981 when the [National Science Foundation](/wiki/National_Science_Foundation "National Science Foundation") (NSF) funded the [Computer Science Network](/wiki/CSNET "CSNET") (CSNET). In 1982, the [Internet Protocol Suite](/wiki/Internet_Protocol_Suite "Internet Protocol Suite") (TCP/IP) was standardized, which permitted worldwide proliferation of interconnected networks. TCP/IP network access expanded again in 1986 when the [National Science Foundation Network](/wiki/National_Science_Foundation_Network "National Science Foundation Network") (NSFNet) provided access to [supercomputer](/wiki/Supercomputer "Supercomputer") sites in the United States for researchers, first at speeds of 56 kbit/s and later at 1.5 Mbit/s and 45 Mbit/s.[[29]](#cite_note-29) The NSFNet expanded into academic and research organizations in Europe, Australia, New Zealand and Japan in 1988–89.[[30]](#cite_note-30)[[31]](#cite_note-31)[[32]](#cite_note-32)[[33]](#cite_note-33) Although other network protocols such as [UUCP](/wiki/UUCP "UUCP") had global reach well before this time, this marked the beginning of the Internet as an intercontinental network. Commercial [Internet service providers](/wiki/Internet_service_providers "Internet service providers") (ISPs) emerged in 1989 in the United States and Australia.[[34]](#cite_note-34) The ARPANET was decommissioned in 1990.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/NSFNET-backbone-T3.png/220px-NSFNET-backbone-T3.png)](/wiki/File:NSFNET-backbone-T3.png)



[](/wiki/File:NSFNET-backbone-T3.png "Enlarge")

T3 [NSFNET](/wiki/NSFNET "NSFNET") Backbone, c. 1992.





Steady advances in [semiconductor](/wiki/Semiconductor "Semiconductor") technology and [optical networking](/wiki/Optical_networking "Optical networking") created new economic opportunities for commercial involvement in the expansion of the network in its core and for delivering services to the public. In mid-1989, MCI Mail and [Compuserve](/wiki/Compuserve "Compuserve") established connections to the Internet, delivering email and public access products to the half million users of the Internet.[[35]](#cite_note-35) Just months later, on 1 January 1990, PSInet launched an alternate Internet backbone for commercial use; one of the networks that added to the core of the commercial Internet of later years. In March 1990, the first high-speed T1 (1.5 Mbit/s) link between the NSFNET and Europe was installed between [Cornell University](/wiki/Cornell_University "Cornell University") and [CERN](/wiki/CERN "CERN"), allowing much more robust communications than were capable with satellites.[[36]](#cite_note-36) Six months later [Tim Berners-Lee](/wiki/Tim_Berners-Lee "Tim Berners-Lee") would begin writing [WorldWideWeb](/wiki/WorldWideWeb "WorldWideWeb"), the first [web browser](/wiki/Web_browser "Web browser") after two years of lobbying CERN management. By Christmas 1990, Berners-Lee had built all the tools necessary for a working Web: the [HyperText Transfer Protocol](/wiki/HyperText_Transfer_Protocol "HyperText Transfer Protocol") (HTTP) 0.9,[[37]](#cite_note-37) the [HyperText Markup Language](/wiki/HyperText_Markup_Language "HyperText Markup Language") (HTML), the first Web browser (which was also a [HTML editor](/wiki/HTML_editor "HTML editor") and could access [Usenet](/wiki/Usenet "Usenet") newsgroups and [FTP](/wiki/FTP "FTP") files), the first HTTP [server software](/wiki/Server_application "Server application") (later known as [CERN httpd](/wiki/CERN_httpd "CERN httpd")), the first [web server](/wiki/Web_server "Web server"),[[38]](#cite_note-38) and the first Web pages that described the project itself. In 1991 the [Commercial Internet eXchange](/wiki/Commercial_Internet_eXchange "Commercial Internet eXchange") was founded, allowing PSInet to communicate with the other commercial networks CERFnet and Alternet. [Stanford Federal Credit Union](/wiki/Stanford_Federal_Credit_Union "Stanford Federal Credit Union") was the first [financial institution](/wiki/Financial_institution "Financial institution") to offer online Internet banking services to all of its members in October 1994.[[39]](#cite_note-39) In 1996, [OP Financial Group](/wiki/OP_Financial_Group "OP Financial Group"), also a [cooperative bank](/wiki/Cooperative_bank "Cooperative bank"), became the second online bank in the world and the first in Europe.[[40]](#cite_note-40) By 1995, the Internet was fully commercialized in the U.S. when the NSFNet was decommissioned, removing the last restrictions on use of the Internet to carry commercial traffic.[[41]](#cite_note-ConneXions-April1996-41)

As technology advanced and commercial opportunities fueled reciprocal growth, the volume of [Internet traffic](/wiki/Internet_traffic "Internet traffic") started experiencing similar characteristics as that of the scaling of [MOS transistors](/wiki/MOS_transistor "MOS transistor"), exemplified by [Moore's law](/wiki/Moore%27s_law "Moore's law"), doubling every 18 months. This growth, formalized as [Edholm's law](/wiki/Edholm%27s_law "Edholm's law"), was catalyzed by advances in [MOS technology](/wiki/MOS_technology "MOS technology"), [laser](/wiki/Laser "Laser") lightwave systems, and [noise](/wiki/Noise_(signal_processing) "Noise (signal processing)") performance.[[44]](#cite_note-Jindal-44)

Since 1995, the Internet has tremendously impacted culture and commerce, including the rise of near instant communication by email, [instant messaging](/wiki/Instant_messaging "Instant messaging"), telephony ([Voice over Internet Protocol](/wiki/Voice_over_Internet_Protocol "Voice over Internet Protocol") or VoIP), [two-way interactive video calls](/wiki/Video_chat "Video chat"), and the [World Wide Web](/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web")[[45]](#cite_note-45) with its [discussion forums](/wiki/Discussion_forums "Discussion forums"), blogs, [social networking services](/wiki/Social_networking_service "Social networking service"), and [online shopping](/wiki/Online_shopping "Online shopping") sites. Increasing amounts of data are transmitted at higher and higher speeds over fiber optic networks operating at 1-Gbit/s, 10-Gbit/s, or more. The Internet continues to grow, driven by ever greater amounts of online information and knowledge, commerce, entertainment and [social networking services](/wiki/Social_networking_service "Social networking service").[[46]](#cite_note-46) During the late 1990s, it was estimated that traffic on the public Internet grew by 100 percent per year, while the mean annual growth in the number of Internet users was thought to be between 20% and 50%.[[47]](#cite_note-47) This growth is often attributed to the lack of central administration, which allows organic growth of the network, as well as the non-proprietary nature of the Internet protocols, which encourages vendor interoperability and prevents any one company from exerting too much control over the network.[[48]](#cite_note-48) As of 31 March 2011[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Internet&action=edit), the estimated total number of [Internet users](/wiki/Internet_users "Internet users") was 2.095 billion (30.2% of world population).[[49]](#cite_note-stats1-49) It is estimated that in 1993 the Internet carried only 1% of the information flowing through two-way [telecommunication](/wiki/Telecommunication "Telecommunication"). By 2000 this figure had grown to 51%, and by 2007 more than 97% of all telecommunicated information was carried over the Internet.[[50]](#cite_note-50)

## Governance

Main article: [Internet governance](/wiki/Internet_governance "Internet governance")



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Icannheadquartersplayavista.jpg/220px-Icannheadquartersplayavista.jpg)](/wiki/File:Icannheadquartersplayavista.jpg)



[](/wiki/File:Icannheadquartersplayavista.jpg "Enlarge")

ICANN headquarters in the [Playa Vista](/wiki/Playa_Vista,_Los_Angeles "Playa Vista, Los Angeles") neighborhood of [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles"), California, United States.





The Internet is a [global network](/wiki/Global_network "Global network") that comprises many voluntarily interconnected autonomous networks. It operates without a central governing body. The technical underpinning and standardization of the core protocols ([IPv4](/wiki/IPv4 "IPv4") and [IPv6](/wiki/IPv6 "IPv6")) is an activity of the [Internet Engineering Task Force](/wiki/Internet_Engineering_Task_Force "Internet Engineering Task Force") (IETF), a non-profit organization of loosely affiliated international participants that anyone may associate with by contributing technical expertise. To maintain interoperability, the principal [name spaces](/wiki/Name_space "Name space") of the Internet are administered by the [Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers](/wiki/Internet_Corporation_for_Assigned_Names_and_Numbers "Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers") (ICANN). ICANN is governed by an international board of directors drawn from across the Internet technical, business, academic, and other non-commercial communities. ICANN coordinates the assignment of unique identifiers for use on the Internet, including [domain names](/wiki/Domain_name "Domain name"), Internet Protocol (IP) addresses, application port numbers in the transport protocols, and many other parameters. Globally unified name spaces are essential for maintaining the global reach of the Internet. This role of ICANN distinguishes it as perhaps the only central coordinating body for the global Internet.[[51]](#cite_note-51)

[Regional Internet registries](/wiki/Regional_Internet_registry "Regional Internet registry") (RIRs) were established for five regions of the world. The [African Network Information Center](/wiki/AfriNIC "AfriNIC") (AfriNIC) for [Africa](/wiki/Africa "Africa"), the [American Registry for Internet Numbers](/wiki/American_Registry_for_Internet_Numbers "American Registry for Internet Numbers") (ARIN) for [North America](/wiki/North_America "North America"), the [Asia-Pacific Network Information Centre](/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Network_Information_Centre "Asia-Pacific Network Information Centre") (APNIC) for [Asia](/wiki/Asia "Asia") and the [Pacific region](/wiki/Pacific_region "Pacific region"), the [Latin American and Caribbean Internet Addresses Registry](/wiki/Latin_American_and_Caribbean_Internet_Addresses_Registry "Latin American and Caribbean Internet Addresses Registry") (LACNIC) for [Latin America](/wiki/Latin_America "Latin America") and the [Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean "Caribbean") region, and the [Réseaux IP Européens – Network Coordination Centre](/wiki/RIPE "RIPE") (RIPE NCC) for [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe"), the [Middle East](/wiki/Middle_East "Middle East"), and [Central Asia](/wiki/Central_Asia "Central Asia") were delegated to assign Internet Protocol address blocks and other Internet parameters to local registries, such as [Internet service providers](/wiki/Internet_service_provider "Internet service provider"), from a designated pool of addresses set aside for each region.

The [National Telecommunications and Information Administration](/wiki/National_Telecommunications_and_Information_Administration "National Telecommunications and Information Administration"), an agency of the [United States Department of Commerce](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Commerce "United States Department of Commerce"), had final approval over changes to the [DNS root zone](/wiki/DNS_root_zone "DNS root zone") until the IANA stewardship transition on 1 October 2016.[[52]](#cite_note-52)[[53]](#cite_note-53)[[54]](#cite_note-54)[[55]](#cite_note-55) The [Internet Society](/wiki/Internet_Society "Internet Society") (ISOC) was founded in 1992 with a mission to _"assure the open development, evolution and use of the Internet for the benefit of all people throughout the world"_.[[56]](#cite_note-56) Its members include individuals (anyone may join) as well as corporations, [organizations](/wiki/Organizations "Organizations"), governments, and universities. Among other activities ISOC provides an administrative home for a number of less formally organized groups that are involved in developing and managing the Internet, including: the [Internet Engineering Task Force](/wiki/Internet_Engineering_Task_Force "Internet Engineering Task Force") (IETF), [Internet Architecture Board](/wiki/Internet_Architecture_Board "Internet Architecture Board") (IAB), [Internet Engineering Steering Group](/wiki/Internet_Engineering_Steering_Group "Internet Engineering Steering Group") (IESG), [Internet Research Task Force](/wiki/Internet_Research_Task_Force "Internet Research Task Force") (IRTF), and [Internet Research Steering Group](/wiki/Internet_Research_Steering_Group "Internet Research Steering Group") (IRSG). On 16 November 2005, the United Nations-sponsored [World Summit on the Information Society](/wiki/World_Summit_on_the_Information_Society "World Summit on the Information Society") in [Tunis](/wiki/Tunis "Tunis") established the [Internet Governance Forum](/wiki/Internet_Governance_Forum "Internet Governance Forum") (IGF) to discuss Internet-related issues.

## Infrastructure

See also: [List of countries by number of Internet users](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_Internet_users "List of countries by number of Internet users") and [List of countries by Internet connection speeds](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Internet_connection_speeds "List of countries by Internet connection speeds")



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/World_map_of_submarine_cables.png/220px-World_map_of_submarine_cables.png)](/wiki/File:World_map_of_submarine_cables.png)



[](/wiki/File:World_map_of_submarine_cables.png "Enlarge")

2007 map showing submarine fiberoptic telecommunication cables around the world.





The communications infrastructure of the Internet consists of its hardware components and a system of software layers that control various aspects of the architecture. As with any computer network, the Internet physically consists of [routers](/wiki/Router_(computing) "Router (computing)"), media (such as cabling and radio links), repeaters, modems etc. However, as an example of [internetworking](/wiki/Internetworking "Internetworking"), many of the network nodes are not necessarily internet equipment per se, the internet packets are carried by other full-fledged networking protocols with the Internet acting as a homogeneous networking standard, running across [heterogeneous](/wiki/Heterogeneous "Heterogeneous") hardware, with the packets guided to their destinations by IP routers.

### Routing and service tiers



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Internet_Connectivity_Distribution_%26_Core.svg/220px-Internet_Connectivity_Distribution_%26_Core.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Internet_Connectivity_Distribution_%26_Core.svg)



[](/wiki/File:Internet_Connectivity_Distribution_%26_Core.svg "Enlarge")

Packet routing across the Internet involves several tiers of Internet service providers.





[Internet service providers](/wiki/Internet_service_provider "Internet service provider") (ISPs) establish the worldwide connectivity between individual networks at various levels of scope. End-users who only access the Internet when needed to perform a function or obtain information, represent the bottom of the routing hierarchy. At the top of the routing hierarchy are the [tier 1 networks](/wiki/Tier_1_network "Tier 1 network"), large telecommunication companies that exchange traffic directly with each other via very high speed [fibre optic cables](/wiki/Fibre_optic_cable "Fibre optic cable") and governed by [peering](/wiki/Peering "Peering") agreements. [Tier 2](/wiki/Tier_2_network "Tier 2 network") and lower level networks buy [Internet transit](/wiki/Internet_transit "Internet transit") from other providers to reach at least some parties on the global Internet, though they may also engage in peering. An ISP may use a single upstream provider for connectivity, or implement [multihoming](/wiki/Multihoming "Multihoming") to achieve redundancy and load balancing. [Internet exchange points](/wiki/Internet_exchange_point "Internet exchange point") are major traffic exchanges with physical connections to multiple ISPs. Large organizations, such as academic institutions, large enterprises, and governments, may perform the same function as ISPs, engaging in peering and purchasing transit on behalf of their internal networks. Research networks tend to interconnect with large subnetworks such as [GEANT](/wiki/GEANT "GEANT"), [GLORIAD](/wiki/GLORIAD "GLORIAD"), [Internet2](/wiki/Internet2 "Internet2"), and the UK's [national research and education network](/wiki/National_research_and_education_network "National research and education network"), [JANET](/wiki/JANET "JANET"). Both the Internet IP routing structure and hypertext links of the World Wide Web are examples of [scale-free networks](/wiki/Scale-free_network "Scale-free network").[[57]](#cite_note-57)[_[disputed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Disputed_statement "Wikipedia:Disputed statement") (for: unclear whether citation supports claim empirically)  – [discuss](/wiki/Talk:Internet#Empirical_evidence_that_hypertext_link_network_is_scale-free "Talk:Internet")_] Computers and [routers](/wiki/Router_(computing) "Router (computing)") use [routing tables](/wiki/Routing_table "Routing table") in their operating system to [direct IP packets](/wiki/IP_forwarding "IP forwarding") to the next-hop router or destination. Routing tables are maintained by manual configuration or automatically by [routing protocols](/wiki/Routing_protocol "Routing protocol"). End-nodes typically use a [default route](/wiki/Default_route "Default route") that points toward an ISP providing transit, while ISP routers use the [Border Gateway Protocol](/wiki/Border_Gateway_Protocol "Border Gateway Protocol") to establish the most efficient routing across the complex connections of the global Internet.

### Access

Common methods of [Internet access](/wiki/Internet_access "Internet access") by users include dial-up with a computer [modem](/wiki/Modem "Modem") via telephone circuits, [broadband](/wiki/Broadband_Internet_access "Broadband Internet access") over [coaxial cable](/wiki/Coaxial_cable "Coaxial cable"), [fiber optics](/wiki/Optical_fiber "Optical fiber") or copper wires, [Wi-Fi](/wiki/Wi-Fi "Wi-Fi"), [satellite](/wiki/Satellite_Internet "Satellite Internet"), and [cellular telephone](/wiki/Mobile_telephony "Mobile telephony") technology (e.g. [3G](/wiki/3G "3G"), [4G](/wiki/4G "4G")). The Internet may often be accessed from computers in libraries and [Internet cafes](/wiki/Internet_cafe "Internet cafe"). [Internet access points](/wiki/Internet_kiosk "Internet kiosk") exist in many public places such as airport halls and coffee shops. Various terms are used, such as _public Internet kiosk_, _public access terminal_, and _Web [payphone](/wiki/Payphone "Payphone")_. Many hotels also have public terminals that are usually fee-based. These terminals are widely accessed for various usages, such as ticket booking, bank deposit, or online payment. Wi-Fi provides wireless access to the Internet via local computer networks. [Hotspots](/wiki/Hotspot_(Wi-Fi) "Hotspot (Wi-Fi)") providing such access include [Wi-Fi cafes](/wiki/Wi-Fi#Internet_access "Wi-Fi"), where users need to bring their own wireless devices such as a laptop or [PDA](/wiki/Personal_Digital_Assistant "Personal Digital Assistant"). These services may be free to all, free to customers only, or fee-based.

[Grassroots](/wiki/Grassroots "Grassroots") efforts have led to [wireless community networks](/wiki/Wireless_community_network "Wireless community network"). Commercial Wi-Fi services that cover large areas are available in many cities, such as [New York](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), [London](/wiki/London "London"), [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"), [Toronto](/wiki/Toronto "Toronto"), [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco"), [Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia "Philadelphia"), [Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago") and [Pittsburgh](/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh"), where the Internet can then be accessed from places such as a park bench.[[58]](#cite_note-58) Experiments have also been conducted with proprietary mobile wireless networks like [Ricochet](/wiki/Ricochet_(Internet_service) "Ricochet (Internet service)"), various high-speed data services over cellular networks, and fixed wireless services. Modern [smartphones](/wiki/Smartphone "Smartphone") can also access the Internet through the cellular carrier network. For Web browsing, these devices provide applications such as [Google Chrome](/wiki/Google_Chrome "Google Chrome"), [Safari](/wiki/Safari_(web_browser) "Safari (web browser)"), and [Firefox](/wiki/Firefox "Firefox") and a wide variety of other Internet software may be installed from app-stores. Internet usage by mobile and tablet devices exceeded desktop worldwide for the first time in October 2016.[[59]](#cite_note-59)

#### Mobile communication



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Number_of_mobile_cellular_subscriptions_2012-2016.svg/159px-Number_of_mobile_cellular_subscriptions_2012-2016.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Number_of_mobile_cellular_subscriptions_2012-2016.svg)



[](/wiki/File:Number_of_mobile_cellular_subscriptions_2012-2016.svg "Enlarge")

Number of mobile cellular subscriptions 2012–2016, [_World Trends in Freedom of Expression and Media Development Global Report 2017/2018_](http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0026/002610/261065e.pdf)





The [International Telecommunication Union](/wiki/International_Telecommunication_Union "International Telecommunication Union") (ITU) estimated that, by the end of 2017, 48% of individual users regularly connect to the Internet, up from 34% in 2012.[[60]](#cite_note-60) [Mobile Internet](/wiki/Mobile_Web "Mobile Web") connectivity has played an important role in expanding access in recent years especially in [Asia and the Pacific](/wiki/Asia-Pacific "Asia-Pacific") and in [Africa](/wiki/Africa "Africa").[[61]](#cite_note-:0-61) The number of unique mobile cellular subscriptions increased from 3.89 billion in 2012 to 4.83 billion in 2016, two-thirds of the world's population, with more than half of subscriptions located in Asia and the Pacific. The number of subscriptions is predicted to rise to 5.69 billion users in 2020.[[62]](#cite_note-:1-62) As of 2016[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Internet&action=edit), almost 60% of the world's population had access to a [4G](/wiki/4G "4G") broadband cellular network, up from almost 50% in 2015 and 11% in 2012.[_[disputed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Disputed_statement "Wikipedia:Disputed statement") – [discuss](/wiki/Talk:Internet#Statistics_on_4G_access_not_found "Talk:Internet")_][[62]](#cite_note-:1-62) The limits that users face on accessing information via mobile applications coincide with a broader process of [fragmentation of the Internet](/wiki/Fragmentation_(computing) "Fragmentation (computing)"). Fragmentation restricts access to media content and tends to affect poorest users the most.[[61]](#cite_note-:0-61)

[Zero-rating](/wiki/Zero-rating "Zero-rating"), the practice of [Internet service providers](/wiki/Internet_service_provider "Internet service provider") allowing users free connectivity to access specific content or applications without cost, has offered opportunities to surmount economic hurdles, but has also been accused by its critics as creating a two-tiered Internet. To address the issues with zero-rating, an alternative model has emerged in the concept of 'equal rating' and is being tested in experiments by [Mozilla](/wiki/Mozilla "Mozilla") and [Orange](/wiki/Orange_S.A. "Orange S.A.") in [Africa](/wiki/Africa "Africa"). Equal rating prevents prioritization of one type of content and zero-rates all content up to a specified data cap. A study published by [Chatham House](/wiki/Chatham_House "Chatham House"), 15 out of 19 countries researched in [Latin America](/wiki/Latin_America "Latin America") had some kind of hybrid or zero-rated product offered. Some countries in the region had a handful of plans to choose from (across all mobile network operators) while others, such as [Colombia](/wiki/Colombia "Colombia"), offered as many as 30 pre-paid and 34 post-paid plans.[[63]](#cite_note-63)

A study of eight countries in the [Global South](/wiki/Global_South "Global South") found that zero-rated data plans exist in every country, although there is a great range in the frequency with which they are offered and actually used in each.[[64]](#cite_note-64) The study looked at the top three to five carriers by market share in Bangladesh, Colombia, Ghana, India, Kenya, Nigeria, Peru and Philippines. Across the 181 plans examined, 13 per cent were offering zero-rated services. Another study, covering [Ghana](/wiki/Ghana "Ghana"), [Kenya](/wiki/Kenya "Kenya"), [Nigeria](/wiki/Nigeria "Nigeria") and [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa"), found [Facebook](/wiki/Facebook "Facebook")'s Free Basics and [Wikipedia Zero](/wiki/Wikipedia_Zero "Wikipedia Zero") to be the most commonly zero-rated content.[[65]](#cite_note-65)

The Internet standards describe a framework known as the [Internet protocol suite](/wiki/Internet_protocol_suite "Internet protocol suite") (also called [TCP/IP](/wiki/TCP/IP "TCP/IP"), based on the first two components.) This is a model architecture that divides methods into a [layered system of protocols](/wiki/Communication_protocol#Layering "Communication protocol"), originally documented in [RFC](/wiki/RFC_(identifier) "RFC (identifier)") [1122](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1122) and [RFC](/wiki/RFC_(identifier) "RFC (identifier)") [1123](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1123).

### Layers

The software layers correspond to the environment or scope in which their services operate. At the top is the [application layer](/wiki/Application_layer "Application layer"), space for the application-specific networking methods used in software applications. For example, a web browser program uses the [client-server](/wiki/Client-server "Client-server") application model and a specific protocol of interaction between servers and clients, while many file-sharing systems use a [peer-to-peer](/wiki/Peer-to-peer "Peer-to-peer") paradigm.

Below this top layer, the [transport layer](/wiki/Transport_layer "Transport layer") connects applications on different hosts with a logical channel through the network with appropriate data exchange methods. It provides several services including ordered, reliable delivery (TCP), and an unreliable datagram service (UDP).

Underlying these layers are the networking technologies that interconnect networks at their borders and exchange traffic across them. The [Internet layer](/wiki/Internet_layer "Internet layer") implements the [Internet Protocol](/wiki/Internet_Protocol "Internet Protocol") which enables computers to identify and locate each other by [Internet Protocol (IP) addresses](/wiki/IP_address "IP address"), and route their traffic via intermediate (transit) networks.[[66]](#cite_note-66) The internet protocol layer code is independent of the type of network that it is physically running over.

At the bottom of the architecture is the [link layer](/wiki/Link_layer "Link layer"), which provides logical connectivity between hosts. The link layer code is usually the only software part customized to the type of physical networking link protocol. Many link layers have been implemented and each operates over a type of network link, such as within a [local area network](/wiki/Local_area_network "Local area network") (LAN) or [wide area network](/wiki/Wide_area_network "Wide area network") (e.g. [Wi-Fi](/wiki/Wi-Fi "Wi-Fi") or [Ethernet](/wiki/Ethernet "Ethernet") or a [dial-up connection](/wiki/Dial-up_Internet_access "Dial-up Internet access"), [ATM](/wiki/Asynchronous_transfer_mode "Asynchronous transfer mode") etc.).



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/UDP_encapsulation.svg/220px-UDP_encapsulation.svg.png)](/wiki/File:UDP_encapsulation.svg)



[](/wiki/File:UDP_encapsulation.svg "Enlarge")

As user data is processed through the protocol stack, each abstraction layer adds encapsulation information at the sending host. Data is transmitted _over the wire_ at the link level between hosts and routers. Encapsulation is removed by the receiving host. Intermediate relays update link encapsulation at each hop, and inspect the IP layer for routing purposes.





### Internet protocol



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/IP_stack_connections.svg/220px-IP_stack_connections.svg.png)](/wiki/File:IP_stack_connections.svg)



[](/wiki/File:IP_stack_connections.svg "Enlarge")

Conceptual data flow in a simple network topology of two hosts (_A_ and _B_) connected by a link between their respective routers. The application on each host executes read and write operations as if the processes were directly connected to each other by some kind of data pipe. After establishment of this pipe, most details of the communication are hidden from each process, as the underlying principles of communication are implemented in the lower protocol layers. In analogy, at the transport layer the communication appears as host-to-host, without knowledge of the application data structures and the connecting routers, while at the internetworking layer, individual network boundaries are traversed at each router.





The most prominent component of the Internet model is the Internet Protocol (IP). IP enables internetworking and, in essence, establishes the Internet itself. Two versions of the Internet Protocol exist, IPV4 and IPV6.

#### IP Addresses



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Example_of_an_iterative_DNS_resolver.svg/220px-Example_of_an_iterative_DNS_resolver.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Example_of_an_iterative_DNS_resolver.svg)



[](/wiki/File:Example_of_an_iterative_DNS_resolver.svg "Enlarge")

A DNS resolver consults three name servers to resolve the domain name user-visible "www.wikipedia.org" to determine the IPV4 Address 207.142.131.234





For locating individual computers on the network, the Internet provides [IP addresses](/wiki/IP_address "IP address"). IP addresses are used by the Internet infrastructure to direct internet packets to their destinations. They consist of fixed-length numbers, which are found within the packet. IP addresses are generally assigned to equipment either automatically via [DHCP](/wiki/DHCP "DHCP"), or are configured.

However the network also supports other addressing systems. Users generally enter [domain names](/wiki/Fully_qualified_domain_name "Fully qualified domain name") (e.g. "en.wikipedia.org") instead of IP addresses because they are easier to remember, they are converted by the [Domain Name System](/wiki/Domain_Name_System "Domain Name System") (DNS) into IP addresses which are more efficient for routing purposes.

#### IPv4

[Internet Protocol version 4](/wiki/IPv4 "IPv4") (IPv4) defines an IP address as a [32-bit](/wiki/32-bit "32-bit") number.[[67]](#cite_note-rfc791-67) [Internet Protocol Version 4](/wiki/IPv4 "IPv4") (IPv4) is the initial version used on the first generation of the Internet and is still in dominant use. It was designed to address up to ≈4.3 billion (109) hosts. However, the explosive growth of the Internet has led to [IPv4 address exhaustion](/wiki/IPv4_address_exhaustion "IPv4 address exhaustion"), which entered its final stage in 2011,[[68]](#cite_note-68) when the global IPv4 address allocation pool was exhausted.

#### IPv6

Because of the growth of the Internet and the [depletion of available IPv4 addresses](/wiki/IPv4_address_exhaustion "IPv4 address exhaustion"), a new version of IP [IPv6](/wiki/IPv6 "IPv6"), was developed in the mid-1990s, which provides vastly larger addressing capabilities and more efficient routing of Internet traffic. IPv6 uses 128 bits for the IP address and was standardized in 1998.[[69]](#cite_note-rfc1883-69)[[70]](#cite_note-rfc2460-70)[[71]](#cite_note-rfc8200-71) [IPv6 deployment](/wiki/IPv6_deployment "IPv6 deployment") has been ongoing since the mid-2000s. [IPv6](/wiki/IPv6 "IPv6") is currently in growing [deployment](/wiki/IPv6_deployment "IPv6 deployment") around the world, since Internet address registries ([RIRs](/wiki/Regional_Internet_registry "Regional Internet registry")) began to urge all resource managers to plan rapid adoption and conversion.[[72]](#cite_note-72)

IPv6 is not directly interoperable by design with IPv4\. In essence, it establishes a parallel version of the Internet not directly accessible with IPv4 software. Thus, translation facilities must exist for internetworking or nodes must have duplicate networking software for both networks. Essentially all modern computer operating systems support both versions of the Internet Protocol. Network infrastructure, however, has been lagging in this development. Aside from the complex array of physical connections that make up its infrastructure, the Internet is facilitated by bi- or multi-lateral commercial contracts, e.g., [peering agreements](/wiki/Peering_agreement "Peering agreement"), and by technical specifications or protocols that describe the exchange of data over the network. Indeed, the Internet is defined by its interconnections and routing policies.

#### Subnetwork



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Subnetting_Concept-en.svg/300px-Subnetting_Concept-en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Subnetting_Concept-en.svg)



[](/wiki/File:Subnetting_Concept-en.svg "Enlarge")

Creating a subnet by dividing the host identifier





A _[subnetwork](/wiki/Subnetwork "Subnetwork")_ or _subnet_ is a logical subdivision of an [IP network](/wiki/IP_network "IP network").[[73]](#cite_note-rfc950-73):1,16 The practice of dividing a network into two or more networks is called _subnetting_.

Computers that belong to a subnet are addressed with an identical [most-significant bit](/wiki/Most-significant_bit "Most-significant bit")-group in their [IP addresses](/wiki/IP_address "IP address"). This results in the logical division of an IP address into two fields, the _network number_ or _routing prefix_ and the _rest field_ or _host identifier_. The _rest field_ is an identifier for a specific [host](/wiki/Host_(network) "Host (network)") or network interface.

The _routing prefix_ may be expressed in [Classless Inter-Domain Routing](/wiki/Classless_Inter-Domain_Routing "Classless Inter-Domain Routing") (CIDR) notation written as the first address of a network, followed by a slash character (_/_), and ending with the bit-length of the prefix. For example, _198.51.100.0/24_ is the prefix of the [Internet Protocol version 4](/wiki/Internet_Protocol_version_4 "Internet Protocol version 4") network starting at the given address, having 24 bits allocated for the network prefix, and the remaining 8 bits reserved for host addressing. Addresses in the range _198.51.100.0_ to _198.51.100.255_ belong to this network. The [IPv6](/wiki/IPv6 "IPv6") address specification _2001:db8::/32_ is a large address block with 296 addresses, having a 32-bit routing prefix.

For IPv4, a network may also be characterized by its _subnet mask_ or _netmask_, which is the [bitmask](/wiki/Bitmask "Bitmask") that when applied by a [bitwise AND](/wiki/Bitwise_AND "Bitwise AND") operation to any IP address in the network, yields the routing prefix. Subnet masks are also expressed in [dot-decimal notation](/wiki/Dot-decimal_notation "Dot-decimal notation") like an address. For example, _255.255.255.0_ is the subnet mask for the prefix _198.51.100.0/24_.

Traffic is exchanged between subnetworks through [routers](/wiki/Router_(computing) "Router (computing)") when the routing prefixes of the source address and the destination address differ. A router serves as a logical or physical boundary between the subnets.

The benefits of subnetting an existing network vary with each deployment scenario. In the address allocation architecture of the Internet using CIDR and in large organizations, it is necessary to allocate address space efficiently. Subnetting may also enhance routing efficiency, or have advantages in network management when subnetworks are administratively controlled by different entities in a larger organization. Subnets may be arranged logically in a hierarchical architecture, partitioning an organization's network address space into a tree-like routing structure.

### IETF

While the hardware components in the Internet infrastructure can often be used to support other software systems, it is the design and the standardization process of the software that characterizes the Internet and provides the foundation for its scalability and success. The responsibility for the architectural design of the Internet software systems has been assumed by the [Internet Engineering Task Force](/wiki/Internet_Engineering_Task_Force "Internet Engineering Task Force") (IETF).[[74]](#cite_note-74) The IETF conducts standard-setting work groups, open to any individual, about the various aspects of Internet architecture. Resulting contributions and standards are published as _[Request for Comments](/wiki/Request_for_Comments "Request for Comments")_ (RFC) documents on the IETF web site. The principal methods of networking that enable the Internet are contained in specially designated RFCs that constitute the [Internet Standards](/wiki/Internet_Standard "Internet Standard"). Other less rigorous documents are simply informative, experimental, or historical, or document the best current practices (BCP) when implementing Internet technologies.

## Applications and services

The Internet carries many [applications and services](/wiki/Network_service "Network service"), most prominently the [World Wide Web](/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web"), including [social media](/wiki/Social_media "Social media"), [electronic mail](/wiki/Electronic_mail "Electronic mail"), [mobile applications](/wiki/Mobile_app "Mobile app"), [multiplayer online games](/wiki/Multiplayer_online_game "Multiplayer online game"), [Internet telephony](/wiki/Internet_telephony "Internet telephony"), [file sharing](/wiki/File_sharing "File sharing"), and [streaming media](/wiki/Streaming_media "Streaming media") services.

Most [servers](/wiki/Server_(computing) "Server (computing)") that provide these services are today hosted in [data centers](/wiki/Data_center "Data center"), and content is often accessed through high-performance [content delivery networks](/wiki/Content_delivery_network "Content delivery network").

### World Wide Web

Main article: [World Wide Web](/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web")



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/First_Web_Server.jpg/220px-First_Web_Server.jpg)](/wiki/File:First_Web_Server.jpg)



[](/wiki/File:First_Web_Server.jpg "Enlarge")

This [NeXT Computer](/wiki/NeXT_Computer "NeXT Computer") was used by [Tim Berners-Lee](/wiki/Tim_Berners-Lee "Tim Berners-Lee") at [CERN](/wiki/CERN "CERN") and became the world's first [Web server](/wiki/Web_server "Web server").





The World Wide Web is a global collection of [documents](/wiki/Documents "Documents"), [images](/wiki/Computer_graphics "Computer graphics"), [multimedia](/wiki/Multimedia "Multimedia"), applications, and other resources, logically interrelated by [hyperlinks](/wiki/Hyperlink "Hyperlink") and referenced with [Uniform Resource Identifiers](/wiki/Uniform_Resource_Identifier "Uniform Resource Identifier") (URIs), which provide a global system of named references. URIs symbolically identify services, [web servers](/wiki/Web_servers "Web servers"), databases, and the documents and resources that they can provide. [Hypertext Transfer Protocol](/wiki/Hypertext_Transfer_Protocol "Hypertext Transfer Protocol") (HTTP) is the main access protocol of the World Wide Web. [Web services](/wiki/Web_service "Web service") also use HTTP for communication between software systems for information transfer, sharing and exchanging business data and logistic and is one of many languages or protocols that can be used for communication on the Internet.[[75]](#cite_note-75)

World Wide Web browser software, such as [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft")'s [Internet Explorer](/wiki/Internet_Explorer "Internet Explorer")/[Edge](/wiki/Microsoft_Edge "Microsoft Edge"), [Mozilla Firefox](/wiki/Mozilla_Firefox "Mozilla Firefox"), [Opera](/wiki/Opera_(web_browser) "Opera (web browser)"), [Apple](/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc.")'s [Safari](/wiki/Safari_(web_browser) "Safari (web browser)"), and [Google Chrome](/wiki/Google_Chrome "Google Chrome"), lets users navigate from one web page to another via the hyperlinks embedded in the documents. These documents may also contain any combination of [computer data](/wiki/Computer_data "Computer data"), including graphics, sounds, [text](/wiki/Plain_text "Plain text"), [video](/wiki/Web_video "Web video"), [multimedia](/wiki/Multimedia "Multimedia") and interactive content that runs while the user is interacting with the page. [Client-side software](/wiki/Client-side_scripting "Client-side scripting") can include animations, [games](/wiki/Web_game "Web game"), [office applications](/wiki/Office_applications "Office applications") and scientific demonstrations. Through [keyword](/wiki/Keyword_(Internet_search) "Keyword (Internet search)")-driven [Internet research](/wiki/Internet_research "Internet research") using [search engines](/wiki/Web_search_engine "Web search engine") like [Yahoo!](/wiki/Yahoo!_Search "Yahoo! Search"), [Bing](/wiki/Bing_(search_engine) "Bing (search engine)") and [Google](/wiki/Google_Search "Google Search"), users worldwide have easy, instant access to a vast and diverse amount of online information. Compared to printed media, books, encyclopedias and traditional libraries, the World Wide Web has enabled the decentralization of information on a large scale.

The Web has enabled individuals and organizations to [publish](/wiki/Publish "Publish") ideas and information to a potentially large [audience](/wiki/Audience "Audience") online at greatly reduced expense and time delay. Publishing a web page, a blog, or building a website involves little initial [cost](/wiki/Cost "Cost") and many cost-free services are available. However, publishing and maintaining large, professional web sites with attractive, diverse and up-to-date information is still a difficult and expensive proposition. Many individuals and some companies and groups use _web logs_ or blogs, which are largely used as easily updatable online diaries. Some commercial organizations encourage [staff](/wiki/Employees "Employees") to communicate advice in their areas of specialization in the hope that visitors will be impressed by the expert knowledge and free information, and be attracted to the corporation as a result.

[Advertising](/wiki/Online_advertising "Online advertising") on popular web pages can be lucrative, and [e-commerce](/wiki/E-commerce "E-commerce"), which is the sale of products and services directly via the Web, continues to grow. Online advertising is a form of [marketing](/wiki/Marketing "Marketing") and advertising which uses the Internet to deliver [promotional](/wiki/Promotion_(marketing) "Promotion (marketing)") marketing messages to consumers. It includes email marketing, [search engine marketing](/wiki/Search_engine_marketing "Search engine marketing") (SEM), social media marketing, many types of [display advertising](/wiki/Display_advertising "Display advertising") (including [web banner](/wiki/Web_banner "Web banner") advertising), and [mobile advertising](/wiki/Mobile_advertising "Mobile advertising"). In 2011, Internet advertising revenues in the United States surpassed those of [cable television](/wiki/Cable_television "Cable television") and nearly exceeded those of [broadcast television](/wiki/Broadcast_television "Broadcast television").[[76]](#cite_note-IAB2012-76):19 Many common online advertising practices are controversial and increasingly subject to regulation.

When the Web developed in the 1990s, a typical web page was stored in completed form on a web server, formatted in [HTML](/wiki/HTML "HTML"), complete for transmission to a web browser in response to a request. Over time, the process of creating and serving web pages has become dynamic, creating a flexible design, layout, and content. Websites are often created using [content management](/wiki/Content_management "Content management") software with, initially, very little content. Contributors to these systems, who may be paid staff, members of an organization or the public, fill underlying databases with content using editing pages designed for that purpose while casual visitors view and read this content in HTML form. There may or may not be editorial, approval and security systems built into the process of taking newly entered content and making it available to the target visitors.

### Communication

[Email](/wiki/Email "Email") is an important communications service available via the Internet. The concept of sending electronic text messages between parties, analogous to mailing letters or memos, predates the creation of the Internet.[[77]](#cite_note-77)[[78]](#cite_note-78) Pictures, documents, and other files are sent as [email attachments](/wiki/Email_attachment "Email attachment"). Email messages can be [cc-ed](/wiki/Carbon_copy "Carbon copy") to multiple [email addresses](/wiki/Email_address "Email address").

[Internet telephony](/wiki/Internet_telephony "Internet telephony") is a common communications service realized with the Internet. The name of the principle internetworking protocol, the [Internet Protocol](/wiki/Internet_Protocol "Internet Protocol"), lends its name to [voice over Internet Protocol](/wiki/Voice_over_Internet_Protocol "Voice over Internet Protocol") (VoIP). The idea began in the early 1990s with [walkie-talkie](/wiki/Walkie-talkie "Walkie-talkie")-like voice applications for personal computers. VoIP systems now dominate many markets, and are as easy to use and as convenient as a traditional telephone. The benefit has been in substantial cost savings over traditional telephone calls, especially over long distances. [Cable](/wiki/Cable_modem "Cable modem"), [ADSL](/wiki/ADSL "ADSL"), and [mobile data](/wiki/Mobile_data "Mobile data") networks provide [Internet access](/wiki/Internet_access "Internet access") in customer premises[[79]](#cite_note-EBSCOhost-79) and inexpensive VoIP network adapters provide the connection for traditional analog telephone sets. The voice quality of VoIP often exceeds that of traditional calls. Remaining problems for VoIP include the situation that emergency services may not be universally available, and that devices rely on a local power supply, while older traditional phones are powered from the local loop, and typically operate during a power failure.

### Data transfer

[File sharing](/wiki/File_sharing "File sharing") is an example of transferring large amounts of data across the Internet. A [computer file](/wiki/Computer_file "Computer file") can be emailed to customers, colleagues and friends as an attachment. It can be uploaded to a website or [File Transfer Protocol](/wiki/File_Transfer_Protocol "File Transfer Protocol") (FTP) server for easy download by others. It can be put into a "shared location" or onto a [file server](/wiki/File_server "File server") for instant use by colleagues. The load of bulk downloads to many users can be eased by the use of "[mirror](/wiki/Web_mirror "Web mirror")" servers or [peer-to-peer](/wiki/Peer-to-peer "Peer-to-peer") networks. In any of these cases, access to the file may be controlled by user [authentication](/wiki/Authentication "Authentication"), the transit of the file over the Internet may be obscured by [encryption](/wiki/Encryption "Encryption"), and money may change hands for access to the file. The price can be paid by the remote charging of funds from, for example, a credit card whose details are also passed—usually fully encrypted—across the Internet. The origin and authenticity of the file received may be checked by [digital signatures](/wiki/Digital_signature "Digital signature") or by [MD5](/wiki/MD5 "MD5") or other message digests. These simple features of the Internet, over a worldwide basis, are changing the production, sale, and distribution of anything that can be reduced to a computer file for transmission. This includes all manner of print publications, software products, news, music, film, video, photography, graphics and the other arts. This in turn has caused seismic shifts in each of the existing industries that previously controlled the production and distribution of these products.

[Streaming media](/wiki/Streaming_media "Streaming media") is the real-time delivery of digital media for the immediate consumption or enjoyment by end users. Many radio and television broadcasters provide Internet feeds of their live audio and video productions. They may also allow time-shift viewing or listening such as Preview, Classic Clips and Listen Again features. These providers have been joined by a range of pure Internet "broadcasters" who never had on-air licenses. This means that an Internet-connected device, such as a computer or something more specific, can be used to access on-line media in much the same way as was previously possible only with a television or radio receiver. The range of available types of content is much wider, from specialized technical [webcasts](/wiki/Webcast "Webcast") to on-demand popular multimedia services. [Podcasting](/wiki/Podcast "Podcast") is a variation on this theme, where—usually audio—material is downloaded and played back on a computer or shifted to a [portable media player](/wiki/Portable_media_player "Portable media player") to be listened to on the move. These techniques using simple equipment allow anybody, with little censorship or licensing control, to broadcast audio-visual material worldwide.

Digital media streaming increases the demand for network bandwidth. For example, standard image quality needs 1 Mbit/s link speed for SD 480p, HD 720p quality requires 2.5 Mbit/s, and the top-of-the-line HDX quality needs 4.5 Mbit/s for 1080p.[[80]](#cite_note-80)

[Webcams](/wiki/Webcam "Webcam") are a low-cost extension of this phenomenon. While some webcams can give full-frame-rate video, the picture either is usually small or updates slowly. Internet users can watch animals around an African waterhole, ships in the [Panama Canal](/wiki/Panama_Canal "Panama Canal"), traffic at a local roundabout or monitor their own premises, live and in real time. Video [chat rooms](/wiki/Chat_rooms "Chat rooms") and [video conferencing](/wiki/Video_conferencing "Video conferencing") are also popular with many uses being found for personal webcams, with and without two-way sound. YouTube was founded on 15 February 2005 and is now the leading website for free streaming video with more than two billion users.[[81]](#cite_note-81) It uses an HTML5 based web player by default to stream and show video files.[[82]](#cite_note-82) Registered users may upload an unlimited amount of video and build their own personal profile. [YouTube](/wiki/YouTube "YouTube") claims that its users watch hundreds of millions, and upload hundreds of thousands of videos daily.

## Social impact

The Internet has enabled new forms of social interaction, activities, and social associations. This phenomenon has given rise to the scholarly study of the [sociology of the Internet](/wiki/Sociology_of_the_Internet "Sociology of the Internet").

From 2000 to 2009, the number of Internet users globally rose from 394 million to 1.858 billion.[[86]](#cite_note-86) By 2010, 22 percent of the world's population had access to computers with 1 billion [Google](/wiki/Google "Google") searches every day, 300 million Internet users reading blogs, and 2 billion videos viewed daily on [YouTube](/wiki/YouTube "YouTube").[[87]](#cite_note-87) In 2014 the world's Internet users surpassed 3 billion or 43.6 percent of world population, but two-thirds of the users came from richest countries, with 78.0 percent of Europe countries population using the Internet, followed by 57.4 percent of the Americas.[[88]](#cite_note-88) However, by 2018, Asia alone accounted for 51% of all Internet users, with 2.2 billion out of the 4.3 billion Internet users in the world coming from that region. The number of China's Internet users surpassed a major milestone in 2018, when the country's Internet regulatory authority, China Internet Network Information Centre, announced that China had 802 million Internet users.[[89]](#cite_note-89) By 2019, China was the world's leading country in terms of Internet users, with more than 800 million users, followed closely by India, with some 700 million users, with the United States a distant third with 275 million users. However, in terms of penetration, China has[_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_] a 38.4% penetration rate compared to India's 40% and the United States's 80%.[[90]](#cite_note-90) As of 2020, it was estimated that 4.5 billion people use the Internet.[[91]](#cite_note-91)

The prevalent language for communication via the Internet has always been English. This may be a result of the origin of the Internet, as well as the language's role as a [lingua franca](/wiki/Lingua_franca "Lingua franca") and as a [world language](/wiki/World_language "World language"). Early computer systems were limited to the characters in the [American Standard Code for Information Interchange](/wiki/ASCII "ASCII") (ASCII), a subset of the [Latin alphabet](/wiki/Latin_alphabet "Latin alphabet").

After English (27%), the most requested languages on the [World Wide Web](/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web") are Chinese (25%), Spanish (8%), Japanese (5%), Portuguese and German (4% each), Arabic, French and Russian (3% each), and Korean (2%).[[92]](#cite_note-NIUBL-IWS-92) By region, 42% of the world's [Internet users](/wiki/Internet_users "Internet users") are based in Asia, 24% in Europe, 14% in North America, 10% in Latin America and the [Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean "Caribbean") taken together, 6% in Africa, 3% in the Middle East and 1% in Australia/Oceania.[[93]](#cite_note-inetstats-93) The Internet's technologies have developed enough in recent years, especially in the use of [Unicode](/wiki/Unicode "Unicode"), that good facilities are available for development and communication in the world's widely used languages. However, some glitches such as _[mojibake](/wiki/Mojibake "Mojibake")_ (incorrect display of some languages' characters) still remain.

In an American study in 2005, the percentage of men using the Internet was very slightly ahead of the percentage of women, although this difference reversed in those under 30\. Men logged on more often, spent more time online, and were more likely to be broadband users, whereas women tended to make more use of opportunities to communicate (such as email). Men were more likely to use the Internet to pay bills, participate in auctions, and for recreation such as downloading music and videos. Men and women were equally likely to use the Internet for shopping and banking.[[94]](#cite_note-94) More recent studies indicate that in 2008, women significantly outnumbered men on most [social networking services](/wiki/Social_networking_service "Social networking service"), such as Facebook and Myspace, although the ratios varied with age.[[95]](#cite_note-95) In addition, women watched more streaming content, whereas men downloaded more.[[96]](#cite_note-96) In terms of blogs, men were more likely to blog in the first place; among those who blog, men were more likely to have a professional blog, whereas women were more likely to have a personal blog.[[97]](#cite_note-97)

Splitting by country, in 2012 Iceland, Norway, Sweden, the Netherlands, and Denmark had the highest [Internet penetration by the number of users](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_Internet_users "List of countries by number of Internet users"), with 93% or more of the population with access.[[98]](#cite_note-ITU-IndividualsUsingTheInternet-98)

Several neologisms exist that refer to Internet users: [Netizen](/wiki/Netizen "Netizen") (as in "citizen of the net")[[99]](#cite_note-99) refers to those [actively involved](/wiki/Online_participation "Online participation") in improving [online communities](/wiki/Virtual_community "Virtual community"), the Internet in general or surrounding political affairs and rights such as [free speech](/wiki/Freedom_of_speech#The_Internet_and_Information_Society "Freedom of speech"),[[100]](#cite_note-100)[[101]](#cite_note-Hauben-101) [Internaut](/w/index.php?title=Internaut&action=edit&redlink=1 "Internaut (page does not exist)") refers to operators or technically highly capable users of the Internet,[[102]](#cite_note-102)[[103]](#cite_note-103) [digital citizen](/wiki/Digital_citizen "Digital citizen") refers to a person using the Internet in order to engage in society, politics, and government participation.[[104]](#cite_note-104)
