The Internet allows greater flexibility in working hours and location, especially with the spread of unmetered high-speed connections. The Internet can be accessed almost anywhere by numerous means, including through [mobile Internet devices](/wiki/Mobile_Internet_device "Mobile Internet device"). Mobile phones, [datacards](/wiki/Datacard "Datacard"), [handheld game consoles](/wiki/Handheld_game_console "Handheld game console") and [cellular routers](/wiki/Cellular_router "Cellular router") allow users to connect to the Internet [wirelessly](/wiki/Wireless "Wireless"). Within the limitations imposed by small screens and other limited facilities of such pocket-sized devices, the services of the Internet, including email and the web, may be available. Service providers may restrict the services offered and mobile data charges may be significantly higher than other access methods.

Educational material at all levels from pre-school to post-doctoral is available from websites. Examples range from [CBeebies](/wiki/CBeebies "CBeebies"), through school and high-school revision guides and [virtual universities](/wiki/Virtual_university "Virtual university"), to access to top-end scholarly literature through the likes of [Google Scholar](/wiki/Google_Scholar "Google Scholar"). For [distance education](/wiki/Distance_education "Distance education"), help with [homework](/wiki/Homework "Homework") and other assignments, self-guided learning, whiling away spare time, or just looking up more detail on an interesting fact, it has never been easier for people to access educational information at any level from anywhere. The Internet in general and the [World Wide Web](/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web") in particular are important enablers of both [formal](/wiki/Education "Education") and [informal education](/wiki/Informal_education "Informal education"). Further, the Internet allows universities, in particular, researchers from the social and behavioral sciences, to conduct research remotely via virtual laboratories, with profound changes in reach and generalizability of findings as well as in communication between scientists and in the publication of results.[[108]](#cite_note-108)

The low cost and nearly instantaneous sharing of ideas, knowledge, and skills have made [collaborative](/wiki/Collaboration "Collaboration") work dramatically easier, with the help of [collaborative software](/wiki/Collaborative_software "Collaborative software"). Not only can a group cheaply communicate and share ideas but the wide reach of the Internet allows such groups more easily to form. An example of this is the [free software movement](/wiki/Free_software_movement "Free software movement"), which has produced, among other things, [Linux](/wiki/Linux "Linux"), [Mozilla Firefox](/wiki/Mozilla_Firefox "Mozilla Firefox"), and [OpenOffice.org](/wiki/OpenOffice.org "OpenOffice.org") (later forked into [LibreOffice](/wiki/LibreOffice "LibreOffice")). Internet chat, whether using an [IRC](/wiki/IRC "IRC") chat room, an [instant messaging](/wiki/Instant_messaging "Instant messaging") system, or a [social networking service](/wiki/Social_networking_service "Social networking service"), allows colleagues to stay in touch in a very convenient way while working at their computers during the day. Messages can be exchanged even more quickly and conveniently than via email. These systems may allow files to be exchanged, drawings and images to be shared, or voice and video contact between team members.

[Content management](/wiki/Content_management "Content management") systems allow collaborating teams to work on shared sets of documents simultaneously without accidentally destroying each other's work. Business and project teams can share calendars as well as documents and other information. Such collaboration occurs in a wide variety of areas including scientific research, software development, conference planning, political activism and creative writing. Social and political collaboration is also becoming more widespread as both Internet access and [computer literacy](/wiki/Computer_literacy "Computer literacy") spread.

The Internet allows computer users to remotely access other computers and information stores easily from any access point. Access may be with [computer security](/wiki/Computer_security "Computer security"), i.e. authentication and encryption technologies, depending on the requirements. This is encouraging new ways of working from home, collaboration and information sharing in many industries. An accountant sitting at home can [audit](/wiki/Audit "Audit") the books of a company based in another country, on a [server](/wiki/Server_(computing) "Server (computing)") situated in a third country that is remotely maintained by IT specialists in a fourth. These accounts could have been created by home-working bookkeepers, in other remote locations, based on information emailed to them from offices all over the world. Some of these things were possible before the widespread use of the Internet, but the cost of private [leased lines](/wiki/Leased_line "Leased line") would have made many of them infeasible in practice. An office worker away from their desk, perhaps on the other side of the world on a business trip or a holiday, can access their emails, access their data using [cloud computing](/wiki/Cloud_computing "Cloud computing"), or open a [remote desktop](/wiki/Remote_Desktop_Protocol "Remote Desktop Protocol") session into their office PC using a secure [virtual private network](/wiki/Virtual_private_network "Virtual private network") (VPN) connection on the Internet. This can give the worker complete access to all of their normal files and data, including email and other applications, while away from the office. It has been referred to among [system administrators](/wiki/System_administrator "System administrator") as the Virtual Private Nightmare,[[109]](#cite_note-109) because it extends the secure perimeter of a corporate network into remote locations and its employees' homes.

### Social networking and entertainment

See also: [Social networking service § Social impact](/wiki/Social_networking_service#Social_impact "Social networking service")

Many people use the World Wide Web to access news, weather and sports reports, to plan and book vacations and to pursue their personal interests. People use [chat](/wiki/Online_chat "Online chat"), messaging and email to make and stay in touch with friends worldwide, sometimes in the same way as some previously had [pen pals](/wiki/Pen_pal "Pen pal"). [Social networking services](/wiki/Social_networking_service "Social networking service") such as [Facebook](/wiki/Facebook "Facebook") have created new ways to socialize and interact. Users of these sites are able to add a wide variety of information to pages, to pursue common interests, and to connect with others. It is also possible to find existing acquaintances, to allow communication among existing groups of people. Sites like [LinkedIn](/wiki/LinkedIn "LinkedIn") foster commercial and business connections. YouTube and [Flickr](/wiki/Flickr "Flickr") specialize in users' videos and photographs. [Social networking services](/wiki/Social_networking_service "Social networking service") are also widely used by businesses and other organizations to promote their brands, to market to their customers and to encourage posts to "[go viral](/wiki/Viral_marketing "Viral marketing")". "Black hat" social media techniques are also employed by some organizations, such as [spam](/wiki/Spamming "Spamming") accounts and [astroturfing](/wiki/Astroturfing "Astroturfing").

A risk for both individuals and organizations writing posts (especially public posts) on [social networking services](/wiki/Social_networking_service "Social networking service"), is that especially foolish or controversial posts occasionally lead to an unexpected and possibly large-scale backlash on social media from other Internet users. This is also a risk in relation to controversial _offline_ behavior, if it is widely made known. The nature of this backlash can range widely from counter-arguments and public mockery, through insults and [hate speech](/wiki/Hate_speech "Hate speech"), to, in extreme cases, rape and death [threats](/wiki/Computer_crime#Threats "Computer crime"). The [online disinhibition effect](/wiki/Online_disinhibition_effect "Online disinhibition effect") describes the tendency of many individuals to behave more stridently or offensively online than they would in person. A significant number of [feminist](/wiki/Feminist "Feminist") women have been the target of various forms of [harassment](/wiki/Harassment "Harassment") in response to posts they have made on social media, and Twitter in particular has been criticised in the past for not doing enough to aid victims of online abuse.[[110]](#cite_note-110)

For organizations, such a backlash can cause overall [brand damage](/wiki/Public_relations "Public relations"), especially if reported by the media. However, this is not always the case, as any brand damage in the eyes of people with an opposing opinion to that presented by the organization could sometimes be outweighed by strengthening the brand in the eyes of others. Furthermore, if an organization or individual gives in to demands that others perceive as wrong-headed, that can then provoke a counter-backlash.

Some websites, such as [Reddit](/wiki/Reddit "Reddit"), have rules forbidding the posting of [personal information](/wiki/Personal_information "Personal information") of individuals (also known as [doxxing](/wiki/Doxxing "Doxxing")), due to concerns about such postings leading to mobs of large numbers of Internet users directing harassment at the specific individuals thereby identified. In particular, the Reddit rule forbidding the posting of personal information is widely understood to imply that all identifying photos and names must be [censored](/wiki/Censored "Censored") in Facebook [screenshots](/wiki/Screenshots "Screenshots") posted to Reddit. However, the interpretation of this rule in relation to public Twitter posts is less clear, and in any case, like-minded people online have many other ways they can use to direct each other's attention to public social media posts they disagree with.

Children also face dangers online such as [cyberbullying](/wiki/Cyberbullying "Cyberbullying") and [approaches by sexual predators](/wiki/Child_grooming "Child grooming"), who sometimes pose as children themselves. Children may also encounter material which they may find upsetting, or material which their parents consider to be not age-appropriate. Due to naivety, they may also post personal information about themselves online, which could put them or their families at risk unless warned not to do so. Many parents choose to enable [Internet filtering](/wiki/Content-control_software "Content-control software"), and/or supervise their children's online activities, in an attempt to protect their children from inappropriate material on the Internet. The most popular [social networking services](/wiki/Social_networking_service "Social networking service"), such as Facebook and Twitter, commonly forbid users under the age of 13\. However, these policies are typically trivial to circumvent by registering an account with a false birth date, and a significant number of children aged under 13 join such sites anyway. [Social networking services](/wiki/Social_networking_service "Social networking service") for younger children, which claim to provide better levels of protection for children, also exist.[[111]](#cite_note-111)

The Internet has been a major outlet for leisure activity since its inception, with entertaining [social experiments](/wiki/Social_experiment "Social experiment") such as [MUDs](/wiki/MUD "MUD") and [MOOs](/wiki/MOO "MOO") being conducted on university servers, and humor-related [Usenet](/wiki/Usenet "Usenet") groups receiving much traffic.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Many [Internet forums](/wiki/Internet_forums "Internet forums") have sections devoted to games and funny videos.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The [Internet pornography](/wiki/Internet_pornography "Internet pornography") and [online gambling](/wiki/Online_gambling "Online gambling") industries have taken advantage of the World Wide Web. Although many governments have attempted to restrict both industries' use of the Internet, in general, this has failed to stop their widespread popularity.[[112]](#cite_note-112)

Another area of leisure activity on the Internet is [multiplayer gaming](/wiki/Multiplayer_gaming "Multiplayer gaming").[[113]](#cite_note-113) This form of recreation creates communities, where people of all ages and origins enjoy the fast-paced world of multiplayer games. These range from [MMORPG](/wiki/MMORPG "MMORPG") to [first-person shooters](/wiki/First-person_shooter "First-person shooter"), from [role-playing video games](/wiki/Role-playing_video_game "Role-playing video game") to [online gambling](/wiki/Online_gambling "Online gambling"). While online gaming has been around since the 1970s, modern modes of online gaming began with subscription services such as [GameSpy](/wiki/GameSpy_Arcade "GameSpy Arcade") and [MPlayer](/wiki/MPlayer.com "MPlayer.com").[[114]](#cite_note-114) Non-subscribers were limited to certain types of game play or certain games. Many people use the Internet to access and download music, movies and other works for their enjoyment and relaxation. Free and fee-based services exist for all of these activities, using centralized servers and distributed peer-to-peer technologies. Some of these sources exercise more care with respect to the original artists' copyrights than others.

Internet usage has been correlated to users' loneliness.[[115]](#cite_note-115) Lonely people tend to use the Internet as an outlet for their feelings and to share their stories with others, such as in the "[I am lonely will anyone speak to me](/wiki/I_am_lonely_will_anyone_speak_to_me "I am lonely will anyone speak to me")" thread.

A 2017 book claimed that the Internet consolidates most aspects of human endeavor into singular arenas of which all of humanity are potential members and competitors, with fundamentally negative impacts on mental health as a result. While successes in each field of activity are pervasively visible and trumpeted, they are reserved for an extremely thin sliver of the world's most exceptional, leaving everyone else behind. Whereas, before the Internet, expectations of success in any field were supported by reasonable probabilities of achievement at the village, suburb, city or even state level, the same expectations in the Internet world are virtually certain to bring disappointment today: there is always someone else, somewhere on the planet, who can do better and take the now one-and-only top spot.[[116]](#cite_note-116)

[Cybersectarianism](/wiki/Cybersectarianism "Cybersectarianism") is a new organizational form which involves: "highly dispersed small groups of practitioners that may remain largely anonymous within the larger social context and operate in relative secrecy, while still linked remotely to a larger network of believers who share a set of practices and texts, and often a common devotion to a particular leader. Overseas supporters provide funding and support; domestic practitioners distribute tracts, participate in acts of resistance, and share information on the internal situation with outsiders. Collectively, members and practitioners of such sects construct viable virtual communities of faith, exchanging personal testimonies and engaging in the collective study via email, on-line chat rooms, and web-based message boards."[[117]](#cite_note-117) In particular, the British government has raised concerns about the prospect of young British Muslims being indoctrinated into Islamic extremism by material on the Internet, being persuaded to join [terrorist](/wiki/Terrorist "Terrorist") groups such as the so-called "[Islamic State](/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant "Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant")", and then potentially committing acts of terrorism on returning to Britain after fighting in Syria or Iraq.

[Cyberslacking](/wiki/Cyberslacking "Cyberslacking") can become a drain on corporate resources; the average UK employee spent 57 minutes a day surfing the Web while at work, according to a 2003 study by Peninsula Business Services.[[118]](#cite_note-118) [Internet addiction disorder](/wiki/Internet_addiction_disorder "Internet addiction disorder") is excessive computer use that interferes with daily life. [Nicholas G. Carr](/wiki/Nicholas_G._Carr "Nicholas G. Carr") believes that Internet use has other [effects on individuals](/wiki/Psychological_effects_of_Internet_use "Psychological effects of Internet use"), for instance improving skills of scan-reading and [interfering](/wiki/Interference_theory "Interference theory") with the deep thinking that leads to true creativity.[[119]](#cite_note-119)

### Electronic business

[Electronic business](/wiki/Electronic_business "Electronic business") (_e-business_) encompasses business processes spanning the entire [value chain](/wiki/Value_chain "Value chain"): purchasing, [supply chain management](/wiki/Supply_chain_management "Supply chain management"), [marketing](/wiki/Marketing "Marketing"), [sales](/wiki/Sales "Sales"), [customer](/wiki/Customer "Customer") service, and business relationship. [E-commerce](/wiki/E-commerce "E-commerce") seeks to add revenue streams using the Internet to build and enhance relationships with clients and partners. According to [International Data Corporation](/wiki/International_Data_Corporation "International Data Corporation"), the size of worldwide e-commerce, when global business-to-business and -consumer transactions are combined, equate to $16 trillion for 2013\. A report by Oxford Economics added those two together to estimate the total size of the [digital economy](/wiki/Digital_economy "Digital economy") at $20.4 trillion, equivalent to roughly 13.8% of global sales.[[120]](#cite_note-120)

While much has been written of the economic advantages of [Internet-enabled commerce](/wiki/Electronic_commerce "Electronic commerce"), there is also evidence that some aspects of the Internet such as maps and location-aware services may serve to reinforce [economic inequality](/wiki/Economic_inequality "Economic inequality") and the [digital divide](/wiki/Digital_divide "Digital divide").[[121]](#cite_note-121) Electronic commerce may be responsible for [consolidation](/wiki/Consolidation_(business) "Consolidation (business)") and the decline of [mom-and-pop](/wiki/Mom-and-pop "Mom-and-pop"), [brick and mortar](/wiki/Brick_and_mortar "Brick and mortar") businesses resulting in increases in [income inequality](/wiki/Income_inequality "Income inequality").[[122]](#cite_note-122)[[123]](#cite_note-123)[[124]](#cite_note-124)

Author [Andrew Keen](/wiki/Andrew_Keen "Andrew Keen"), a long-time critic of the social transformations caused by the Internet, has focused on the economic effects of consolidation from Internet businesses. Keen cites a 2013 [Institute for Local Self-Reliance](/wiki/Institute_for_Local_Self-Reliance "Institute for Local Self-Reliance") report saying brick-and-mortar retailers employ 47 people for every $10 million in sales while Amazon employs only 14\. Similarly, the 700-employee room rental start-up [Airbnb](/wiki/Airbnb "Airbnb") was valued at $10 billion in 2014, about half as much as [Hilton Worldwide](/wiki/Hilton_Worldwide "Hilton Worldwide"), which employs 152,000 people. At that time, [Uber](/wiki/Uber "Uber") employed 1,000 full-time employees and was valued at $18.2 billion, about the same valuation as [Avis Rent a Car](/wiki/Avis_Rent_a_Car "Avis Rent a Car") and [The Hertz Corporation](/wiki/The_Hertz_Corporation "The Hertz Corporation") combined, which together employed almost 60,000 people.[[125]](#cite_note-125)

### Telecommuting

[Telecommuting](/wiki/Telecommuting "Telecommuting") is the performance within a traditional worker and employer relationship when it is facilitated by tools such as [groupware](/wiki/Groupware "Groupware"), [virtual private networks](/wiki/Virtual_private_networks "Virtual private networks"), [conference calling](/wiki/Conference_calling "Conference calling"), [videoconferencing](/wiki/Videoconferencing "Videoconferencing"), and [voice over IP](/wiki/Voice_over_IP "Voice over IP") (VOIP) so that work may be performed from any location, most conveniently the worker's home. It can be efficient and useful for companies as it allows workers to communicate over long distances, saving significant amounts of travel time and cost. As [broadband](/wiki/Broadband "Broadband") Internet connections become commonplace, more workers have adequate bandwidth at home to use these tools to link their home to their corporate [intranet](/wiki/Intranet "Intranet") and internal communication networks.

### Collaborative publishing

[Wikis](/wiki/Wiki "Wiki") have also been used in the academic community for sharing and dissemination of information across institutional and international boundaries.[[126]](#cite_note-126) In those settings, they have been found useful for collaboration on [grant writing](/wiki/Grant_writing "Grant writing"), [strategic planning](/wiki/Strategic_planning "Strategic planning"), departmental documentation, and committee work.[[127]](#cite_note-127) The [United States Patent and Trademark Office](/wiki/United_States_Patent_and_Trademark_Office "United States Patent and Trademark Office") uses a wiki to allow the public to collaborate on finding [prior art](/wiki/Prior_art "Prior art") relevant to examination of pending patent applications. [Queens](/wiki/Queens "Queens"), New York has used a wiki to allow citizens to collaborate on the design and planning of a local park.[[128]](#cite_note-Noveck-128) The [English Wikipedia](/wiki/English_Wikipedia "English Wikipedia") has the largest user base among wikis on the World Wide Web[[129]](#cite_note-129) and ranks in the top 10 among all Web sites in terms of traffic.[[130]](#cite_note-130)

### Politics and political revolutions

See also: [Internet censorship](/wiki/Internet_censorship "Internet censorship"), [Mass surveillance](/wiki/Mass_surveillance "Mass surveillance"), and [Social media use in politics](/wiki/Social_media_use_in_politics "Social media use in politics")



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Thai-coup-detat-2014-social-media-banner.jpg/220px-Thai-coup-detat-2014-social-media-banner.jpg)](/wiki/File:Thai-coup-detat-2014-social-media-banner.jpg)



[](/wiki/File:Thai-coup-detat-2014-social-media-banner.jpg "Enlarge")

Banner in [Bangkok](/wiki/Bangkok "Bangkok") during the [2014 Thai coup d'état](/wiki/2014_Thai_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat "2014 Thai coup d'état"), informing the [Thai](/wiki/Thailand "Thailand") public that 'like' or 'share' activities on social media could result in imprisonment (observed 30 June 2014).





The Internet has achieved new relevance as a political tool. The presidential campaign of [Howard Dean](/wiki/Howard_Dean "Howard Dean") in 2004 in the United States was notable for its success in soliciting donation via the Internet. Many political groups use the Internet to achieve a new method of organizing for carrying out their mission, having given rise to [Internet activism](/wiki/Internet_activism "Internet activism"), most notably practiced by rebels in the [Arab Spring](/wiki/Arab_Spring "Arab Spring").[[131]](#cite_note-cascading-131)[[132]](#cite_note-132) _[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ suggested that [social media](/wiki/Social_media "Social media") websites, such as Facebook and Twitter, helped people organize the political revolutions in Egypt, by helping activists organize protests, communicate grievances, and disseminate information.[[133]](#cite_note-133)

Many have understood the Internet as an extension of the [Habermasian](/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Habermas "Jürgen Habermas") notion of the _[public sphere](/wiki/Public_sphere "Public sphere")_, observing how network communication technologies provide something like a global civic forum. However, incidents of politically motivated [Internet censorship](/wiki/Internet_censorship "Internet censorship") have now been recorded in many countries, including western democracies.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Philanthropy

The spread of low-cost Internet access in developing countries has opened up new possibilities for [peer-to-peer](/wiki/Social_peer-to-peer_processes "Social peer-to-peer processes") charities, which allow individuals to contribute small amounts to charitable projects for other individuals. Websites, such as [DonorsChoose](/wiki/DonorsChoose "DonorsChoose") and [GlobalGiving](/wiki/GlobalGiving "GlobalGiving"), allow small-scale donors to direct funds to individual projects of their choice. A popular twist on Internet-based philanthropy is the use of [peer-to-peer lending](/wiki/Peer-to-peer_lending "Peer-to-peer lending") for charitable purposes. [Kiva](/wiki/Kiva_(organization) "Kiva (organization)") pioneered this concept in 2005, offering the first web-based service to publish individual loan profiles for funding. Kiva raises funds for local intermediary [microfinance](/wiki/Microfinance "Microfinance") organizations which post stories and updates on behalf of the borrowers. Lenders can contribute as little as $25 to loans of their choice, and receive their money back as borrowers repay. Kiva falls short of being a pure peer-to-peer charity, in that loans are disbursed before being funded by lenders and borrowers do not communicate with lenders themselves.[[134]](#cite_note-134)[[135]](#cite_note-135)

## Security

Main article: [Internet security](/wiki/Internet_security "Internet security")

Internet resources, hardware, and software components are the target of criminal or malicious attempts to gain unauthorized control to cause interruptions, commit fraud, engage in blackmail or access private information.

### Malware

[Malware](/wiki/Malware "Malware") is malicious software used and distributed via the Internet. It includes [computer viruses](/wiki/Computer_virus "Computer virus") which are copied with the help of humans, [computer worms](/wiki/Computer_worm "Computer worm") which copy themselves automatically, software for [denial of service attacks](/wiki/Denial_of_service_attack "Denial of service attack"), [ransomware](/wiki/Ransomware "Ransomware"), [botnets](/wiki/Botnet "Botnet"), and [spyware](/wiki/Spyware "Spyware") that reports on the activity and typing of users. Usually, these activities constitute [cybercrime](/wiki/Cybercrime "Cybercrime"). Defense theorists have also speculated about the possibilities of [hackers](/wiki/Hackers "Hackers") using [cyber warfare](/wiki/Cyber_warfare "Cyber warfare") using similar methods on a large scale.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Surveillance

Main article: [Computer and network surveillance](/wiki/Computer_and_network_surveillance "Computer and network surveillance")

See also: [Signals intelligence](/wiki/Signals_intelligence "Signals intelligence") and [Mass surveillance](/wiki/Mass_surveillance "Mass surveillance")

The vast majority of computer surveillance involves the monitoring of [data](/wiki/Data_mining "Data mining") and [traffic](/wiki/Traffic_analysis "Traffic analysis") on the Internet.[[136]](#cite_note-sciam-internet-136) In the United States for example, under the [Communications Assistance For Law Enforcement Act](/wiki/Communications_Assistance_For_Law_Enforcement_Act "Communications Assistance For Law Enforcement Act"), all phone calls and broadband Internet traffic (emails, web traffic, instant messaging, etc.) are required to be available for unimpeded real-time monitoring by Federal law enforcement agencies.[[137]](#cite_note-eff-calea-archive-137)[[138]](#cite_note-eff-calea-summary-138)[[139]](#cite_note-eff-calea-faq-139) [Packet capture](/wiki/Packet_capture "Packet capture") is the monitoring of data traffic on a [computer network](/wiki/Computer_network "Computer network"). Computers communicate over the Internet by breaking up messages (emails, images, videos, web pages, files, etc.) into small chunks called "packets", which are routed through a network of computers, until they reach their destination, where they are assembled back into a complete "message" again. [Packet Capture Appliance](/wiki/Packet_Capture_Appliance "Packet Capture Appliance") intercepts these packets as they are traveling through the network, in order to examine their contents using other programs. A packet capture is an information _gathering_ tool, but not an _analysis_ tool. That is it gathers "messages" but it does not analyze them and figure out what they mean. Other programs are needed to perform [traffic analysis](/wiki/Traffic_analysis "Traffic analysis") and sift through intercepted data looking for important/useful information. Under the [Communications Assistance For Law Enforcement Act](/wiki/Communications_Assistance_For_Law_Enforcement_Act "Communications Assistance For Law Enforcement Act") all U.S. telecommunications providers are required to install packet sniffing technology to allow Federal law enforcement and intelligence agencies to intercept all of their customers' [broadband Internet](/wiki/Broadband_Internet "Broadband Internet") and [voice over Internet protocol](/wiki/Voice_over_Internet_protocol "Voice over Internet protocol") (VoIP) traffic.[[140]](#cite_note-140)

The large amount of data gathered from packet capturing requires surveillance software that filters and reports relevant information, such as the use of certain words or phrases, the access of certain types of web sites, or communicating via email or chat with certain parties.[[141]](#cite_note-usatoday-chatroom-141) Agencies, such as the [Information Awareness Office](/wiki/Information_Awareness_Office "Information Awareness Office"), [NSA](/wiki/NSA "NSA"), [GCHQ](/wiki/GCHQ "GCHQ") and the [FBI](/wiki/FBI "FBI"), spend billions of dollars per year to develop, purchase, implement, and operate systems for interception and analysis of data.[[142]](#cite_note-zdnet-fbi-142) Similar systems are operated by [Iranian secret police](/wiki/Ministry_of_Intelligence_and_National_Security_of_Iran "Ministry of Intelligence and National Security of Iran") to identify and suppress dissidents. The required hardware and software was allegedly installed by German [Siemens AG](/wiki/Siemens_AG "Siemens AG") and Finnish [Nokia](/wiki/Nokia "Nokia").[[143]](#cite_note-143)

Some governments, such as those of [Burma](/wiki/Burma "Burma"), [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran"), [North Korea](/wiki/Censorship_in_North_Korea "Censorship in North Korea"), [Mainland China](/wiki/Censorship_in_China "Censorship in China"), [Saudi Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia "Saudi Arabia") and the [United Arab Emirates](/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates "United Arab Emirates"), restrict access to content on the Internet within their territories, especially to political and religious content, with domain name and keyword filters.[[149]](#cite_note-149)

In Norway, Denmark, Finland, and Sweden, major Internet service providers have voluntarily agreed to restrict access to sites listed by authorities. While this list of forbidden resources is supposed to contain only known child pornography sites, the content of the list is secret.[[150]](#cite_note-The_Register-150) Many countries, including the United States, have enacted laws against the possession or distribution of certain material, such as [child pornography](/wiki/Child_pornography "Child pornography"), via the Internet, but do not mandate filter software. Many free or commercially available software programs, called [content-control software](/wiki/Content-control_software "Content-control software") are available to users to block offensive websites on individual computers or networks, in order to limit access by children to pornographic material or depiction of violence.

## Performance

As the Internet is a heterogeneous network, the physical characteristics, including for example the [data transfer rates](/wiki/Bit_rate "Bit rate") of connections, vary widely. It exhibits [emergent phenomena](/wiki/Emergence#World_Wide_Web_and_the_Internet "Emergence") that depend on its large-scale organization.[[151]](#cite_note-151)

### Traffic volume







**Global Internet Traffic**

![](/api/rest_v1/page/graph/png/Internet/0/8e8a9e85b35e959b1acaf7863ed42a5be56f0b07.png)









The volume of [Internet traffic](/wiki/Internet_traffic "Internet traffic") is difficult to measure, because no single point of measurement exists in the multi-tiered, non-hierarchical topology. Traffic data may be estimated from the aggregate volume through the peering points of the [Tier 1 network](/wiki/Tier_1_network "Tier 1 network") providers, but traffic that stays local in large provider networks may not be accounted for.

### Outages

An Internet blackout or outage can be caused by local signalling interruptions. Disruptions of [submarine communications cables](/wiki/Submarine_communications_cable "Submarine communications cable") may cause blackouts or slowdowns to large areas, such as in the [2008 submarine cable disruption](/wiki/2008_submarine_cable_disruption "2008 submarine cable disruption"). Less-developed countries are more vulnerable due to a small number of high-capacity links. Land cables are also vulnerable, as in 2011 when a woman digging for scrap metal severed most connectivity for the nation of Armenia.[[152]](#cite_note-152) Internet blackouts affecting almost entire countries can be achieved by governments as a form of [Internet censorship](/wiki/Internet_censorship "Internet censorship"), as in the blockage of the [Internet in Egypt](/wiki/Internet_in_Egypt "Internet in Egypt"), whereby approximately 93%[[153]](#cite_note-renesys1-153) of networks were without access in 2011 in an attempt to stop mobilization for [anti-government protests](/wiki/Egyptian_Revolution_of_2011 "Egyptian Revolution of 2011").[[154]](#cite_note-154)

### Energy use

Estimates of the Internet's electricity usage have been the subject of controversy, according to a 2014 peer-reviewed research paper that found claims differing by a factor of 20,000 published in the literature during the preceding decade, ranging from 0.0064 kilowatt hours per gigabyte transferred (kWh/GB) to 136 kWh/GB.[[155]](#cite_note-:3-155) The researchers attributed these discrepancies mainly to the year of reference (i.e. whether efficiency gains over time had been taken into account) and to whether "end devices such as personal computers and servers are included" in the analysis.[[155]](#cite_note-:3-155)

In 2011, academic researchers estimated the overall energy used by the Internet to be between 170 and 307 GW, less than two percent of the energy used by humanity. This estimate included the energy needed to build, operate, and periodically replace the estimated 750 million laptops, a billion smart phones and 100 million servers worldwide as well as the energy that routers, cell towers, optical switches, Wi-Fi transmitters and cloud storage devices use when transmitting Internet traffic.[[156]](#cite_note-156)[[157]](#cite_note-157) According to a non-peer reviewed study published in 2018 by [The Shift Project](/wiki/The_Shift_Project "The Shift Project") (a French think tank funded by corporate sponsors), nearly 4% of global CO2 emissions could be attributed to global data transfer and the necessary infrastructure.[[158]](#cite_note-158) The study also said that [online video streaming](/wiki/Internet_video "Internet video") alone accounted for 60% of this data transfer and therefore contributed to over 300 million tons of CO2 emission per year, and argued for new "digital sobriety" regulations restricting the use and size of video files.[[159]](#cite_note-159)

In the early 1970s Mr Pouzin created an innovative data network that linked locations in France, Italy and Britain. Its simplicity and efficiency pointed the way to a network that could connect not just dozens of machines, but millions of them. It captured the imagination of Dr Cerf and Dr Kahn, who included aspects of its design in the protocols that now power the internet.

title: ASP.NET Core
content:
**ASP.NET Core** is a [free and open-source](/wiki/Free_and_open-source "Free and open-source") [web framework](/wiki/Web_framework "Web framework") and successor to [ASP.NET](/wiki/ASP.NET "ASP.NET"),[[3]](#cite_note-3) developed by [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft").[[4]](#cite_note-4) It is a modular framework that runs on both the full [.NET Framework](/wiki/.NET_Framework ".NET Framework"), on [Windows](/wiki/Windows "Windows"), and the [cross-platform](/wiki/Cross-platform "Cross-platform") [.NET Core](/wiki/.NET_Core ".NET Core"). However ASP.NET Core version 3 works only on .NET Core dropping support of .NET Framework.[[5]](#cite_note-5)

The framework is a complete rewrite that unites the previously separate [ASP.NET MVC](/wiki/ASP.NET_MVC "ASP.NET MVC") and [ASP.NET Web API](/wiki/ASP.NET_Web_API "ASP.NET Web API") into a single [programming model](/wiki/Programming_model "Programming model").

Despite being a new framework, built on a new web stack, it does have a high degree of concept compatibility with ASP.NET. ASP.NET Core applications supports side by side versioning in which different applications, running on the same machine, can target different versions of ASP.NET Core. This is not possible with previous versions of ASP.NET. Developers can build new web applications by following the MVC architectural pattern and can create a new project in MS Visual Studio 2019 by using ASP.NET Core Web Application template. [[6]](#cite_note-Reasons_to_Choose_the_ASP.Net_Core_for_Web_Development-6)


## Contents



*   [1 Release history](#Release_history)
*   [2 Naming](#Naming)
*   [3 Features](#Features)
*   [4 Components](#Components)
*   [5 See also](#See_also)
*   [6 References](#References)
*   [7 External links](#External_links)

## Naming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASP.NET_Core&action=edit§ion=2 "Edit section: Naming")]

Originally deemed **ASP.NET vNext**, the framework was going to be called **ASP.NET 5** when ready. However, in order to avoid implying it is an update to the existing ASP.NET framework, Microsoft later changed the name to ASP.NET Core at the 1.0 release.[[12]](#cite_note-12)

## Features[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASP.NET_Core&action=edit§ion=3 "Edit section: Features")]

*   No-compile developer experience (i.e. compilation is continuous, so that the developer does not have to invoke the compilation command)
*   Modular framework distributed as [NuGet](/wiki/NuGet "NuGet") packages
*   Cloud-optimized runtime (optimized for the internet)
*   Host-agnostic via [Open Web Interface for .NET](/wiki/Open_Web_Interface_for_.NET "Open Web Interface for .NET") (OWIN) support[[13]](#cite_note-13)[[14]](#cite_note-14) – runs in [IIS](/wiki/Internet_Information_Services "Internet Information Services") or standalone
*   A unified story for building web UI and web APIs (i.e. both the same)
*   A cloud-ready environment-based configuration system
*   A light-weight and modular HTTP request pipeline
*   Build and run cross-platform ASP.NET Core apps on Windows, Mac, and Linux
*   Open-source and community-focused
*   Side-by-side app versioning when targeting .NET Core.
*   Inbuilt support for [dependency injection](/wiki/Dependency_injection "Dependency injection")

## Components[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASP.NET_Core&action=edit§ion=4 "Edit section: Components")]

*   [Entity Framework (EF) Core](/wiki/Entity_Framework "Entity Framework")
*   Identity Core
*   [MVC](/wiki/ASP.NET_MVC "ASP.NET MVC") Core
*   [Razor](/wiki/ASP.NET_Razor "ASP.NET Razor") Core
*   [SignalR](/wiki/SignalR "SignalR")
*   [Blazor](/wiki/Blazor "Blazor")

title: IP address
content:
Numerical label used to identify a network interface in an IP network



For the Wikipedia user access level, see [Wikipedia:User access levels § Unregistered (IP or not logged in) users](/wiki/Wikipedia:User_access_levels#Unregistered_(IP_or_not_logged_in)_users "Wikipedia:User access levels").



An **Internet Protocol address** (**IP address**) is a numerical label assigned to each device connected to a [computer network](/wiki/Computer_network "Computer network") that uses the [Internet Protocol](/wiki/Internet_Protocol "Internet Protocol") for communication.[[1]](#cite_note-rfc760-1)[[2]](#cite_note-rfc791-2) An IP address serves two main functions: host or network interface [identification](/wiki/Identification_(information) "Identification (information)") and location [addressing](/wiki/Network_address "Network address").

[Internet Protocol version 4](/wiki/IPv4 "IPv4") (IPv4) defines an IP address as a [32-bit](/wiki/32-bit "32-bit") number.[[2]](#cite_note-rfc791-2) However, because of the growth of the [Internet](/wiki/Internet "Internet") and the [depletion of available IPv4 addresses](/wiki/IPv4_address_exhaustion "IPv4 address exhaustion"), a new version of IP ([IPv6](/wiki/IPv6 "IPv6")), using 128 bits for the IP address, was standardized in 1998.[[3]](#cite_note-rfc1883-3)[[4]](#cite_note-rfc2460-4)[[5]](#cite_note-rfc8200-5) [IPv6 deployment](/wiki/IPv6_deployment "IPv6 deployment") has been ongoing since the mid-2000s.

IP addresses are written and displayed in [human-readable](/wiki/Human-readable "Human-readable") notations, such as _172.16.254.1_ in IPv4, and _2001:db8:0:1234:0:567:8:1_ in IPv6\. The size of the routing prefix of the address is designated in [CIDR notation](/wiki/CIDR_notation "CIDR notation") by suffixing the address with the number of [significant bits](/wiki/Bit_numbering "Bit numbering"), e.g., _192.168.1.15/24_, which is equivalent to the historically used [subnet mask](/wiki/Subnet_mask "Subnet mask") _255.255.255.0_.

The IP address space is managed globally by the [Internet Assigned Numbers Authority](/wiki/Internet_Assigned_Numbers_Authority "Internet Assigned Numbers Authority") (IANA), and by five [regional Internet registries](/wiki/Regional_Internet_registry "Regional Internet registry") (RIRs) responsible in their designated territories for assignment to [local Internet registries](/wiki/Local_Internet_registry "Local Internet registry"), such as [Internet service providers](/wiki/Internet_service_providers "Internet service providers") (ISPs), and other [end users](/wiki/End_user "End user"). IPv4 addresses were distributed by IANA to the RIRs in blocks of approximately 16.8 million addresses each, but have been exhausted at the IANA level since 2011\. Only one of the RIRs still has a supply for local assignments in Africa.[[6]](#cite_note-6) Some IPv4 addresses are reserved for [private networks](/wiki/Private_network "Private network") and are not globally unique.

[Network administrators](/wiki/Network_administrator "Network administrator") assign an IP address to each device connected to a network. Such assignments may be on a _static_ (fixed or permanent) or _dynamic_ basis, depending on network practices and [software](/wiki/Software "Software") features.





## Contents



*   [1 Function](#Function)
*   [2 IP versions](#IP_versions)
*   [3 Subnetworks](#Subnetworks)
*   [4 IPv4 addresses](#IPv4_addresses)
    *   [4.1 Subnetting history](#Subnetting_history)
    *   [4.2 Private addresses](#Private_addresses)
*   [5 IPv6 addresses](#IPv6_addresses)
    *   [5.1 Private addresses](#Private_addresses_2)
*   [6 IP address assignment](#IP_address_assignment)
    *   [6.1 Sticky dynamic IP address](#Sticky_dynamic_IP_address)
    *   [6.2 Address autoconfiguration](#Address_autoconfiguration)
    *   [6.3 Addressing conflicts](#Addressing_conflicts)
*   [7 Routing](#Routing)
    *   [7.1 Unicast addressing](#Unicast_addressing)
    *   [7.2 Broadcast addressing](#Broadcast_addressing)
    *   [7.3 Multicast addressing](#Multicast_addressing)
    *   [7.4 Anycast addressing](#Anycast_addressing)
*   [8 Geolocation](#Geolocation)
*   [9 Public address](#Public_address)
*   [10 Firewalling](#Firewalling)
*   [11 Address translation](#Address_translation)
*   [12 Diagnostic tools](#Diagnostic_tools)
*   [13 See also](#See_also)
*   [14 References](#References)



## Function

An IP address serves two principal functions. It [identifies](/wiki/Identification_(information) "Identification (information)") the host, or more specifically its network interface, and it provides the location of the host in the network, and thus the capability of establishing a path to that host. Its role has been characterized as follows: "A name indicates what we seek. An address indicates where it is. A route indicates how to get there."[[2]](#cite_note-rfc791-2) The [header](/wiki/Header_(computing) "Header (computing)") of each [IP packet](/wiki/Network_packet "Network packet") contains the IP address of the sending host, and that of the destination host.

## IP versions

Two [versions of the Internet Protocol](/wiki/Internet_Protocol#Version_history "Internet Protocol") are in common use on the Internet today. The original version of the Internet Protocol that was first deployed in 1983 in the [ARPANET](/wiki/ARPANET "ARPANET"), the predecessor of the Internet, is [Internet Protocol version 4](/wiki/IPv4 "IPv4") (IPv4).

The rapid [exhaustion of IPv4 address space](/wiki/IPv4_address_exhaustion "IPv4 address exhaustion") available for assignment to [Internet service providers](/wiki/Internet_service_providers "Internet service providers") and end-user organizations by the early 1990s, prompted the [Internet Engineering Task Force](/wiki/Internet_Engineering_Task_Force "Internet Engineering Task Force") (IETF) to explore new technologies to expand the addressing capability on the Internet. The result was a redesign of the Internet Protocol which became eventually known as [Internet Protocol Version 6](/wiki/IPv6 "IPv6") (IPv6) in 1995.[[3]](#cite_note-rfc1883-3)[[4]](#cite_note-rfc2460-4)[[5]](#cite_note-rfc8200-5) IPv6 technology was in various testing stages until the mid-2000s when commercial production deployment commenced.

Today, these two versions of the Internet Protocol are in simultaneous use. Among other technical changes, each version defines the format of addresses differently. Because of the historical prevalence of IPv4, the generic term _IP address_ typically still refers to the addresses defined by IPv4\. The gap in version sequence between IPv4 and IPv6 resulted from the assignment of version 5 to the experimental [Internet Stream Protocol](/wiki/Internet_Stream_Protocol "Internet Stream Protocol") in 1979, which however was never referred to as IPv5.

Other versions v1 to v9 were defined, but only v4 and v6 ever gained widespread use. v1 and v2 were names for [TCP protocols](/wiki/TCP_protocols "TCP protocols") in 1974 and 1977, as there was to separate IP specification at the time. v3 was defined in 1978, and v3.1 is the first version where TCP is separated from IP. v6 is a synthesis of several suggested versions, v6 _Simple Internet Protocol_, v7 _TP/IX: The Next Internet_, v8 _PIP — The P Internet Protocol_, and v9 _TUBA — Tcp & Udp with Big Addresses_.[[7]](#cite_note-delong2017-7)

## Subnetworks

IP networks may be divided into [subnetworks](/wiki/Subnetwork "Subnetwork") in both [IPv4](/wiki/IPv4_subnetting_reference "IPv4 subnetting reference") and [IPv6](/wiki/IPv6_subnetting_reference "IPv6 subnetting reference"). For this purpose, an IP address is recognized as consisting of two parts: the _network prefix_ in the high-order bits and the remaining bits called the _rest field_, _host identifier_, or _interface identifier_ (IPv6), used for host numbering within a network.[[1]](#cite_note-rfc760-1) The [subnet mask](/wiki/Subnet_mask "Subnet mask") or [CIDR notation](/wiki/CIDR_notation "CIDR notation") determines how the IP address is divided into network and host parts.

The term _subnet mask_ is only used within IPv4\. Both IP versions however use the CIDR concept and notation. In this, the IP address is followed by a slash and the number (in decimal) of bits used for the network part, also called the _routing prefix_. For example, an IPv4 address and its subnet mask may be _192.0.2.1_ and _255.255.255.0_, respectively. The CIDR notation for the same IP address and subnet is _192.0.2.1/24_, because the first 24 bits of the IP address indicate the network and subnet.

## IPv4 addresses

Main article: [IPv4 § Addressing](/wiki/IPv4#Addressing "IPv4")



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ipv4_address.svg/300px-Ipv4_address.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Ipv4_address.svg)



[](/wiki/File:Ipv4_address.svg "Enlarge")

Decomposition of an IPv4 address from [dot-decimal notation](/wiki/Dot-decimal_notation "Dot-decimal notation") to its binary value.





An IPv4 address has a size of 32 bits, which limits the [address space](/wiki/Address_space "Address space") to 4294967296 (232) addresses. Of this number, some addresses are reserved for special purposes such as [private networks](/wiki/Private_network "Private network") (~18 million addresses) and [multicast addressing](/wiki/Multicast_address "Multicast address") (~270 million addresses).

IPv4 addresses are usually represented in [dot-decimal notation](/wiki/Dot-decimal_notation "Dot-decimal notation"), consisting of four decimal numbers, each ranging from 0 to 255, separated by dots, e.g., _172.16.254.1_. Each part represents a group of 8 bits (an [octet](/wiki/Octet_(computing) "Octet (computing)")) of the address. In some cases of technical writing,[_[specify](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] IPv4 addresses may be presented in various [hexadecimal](/wiki/Hexadecimal "Hexadecimal"), [octal](/wiki/Octal "Octal"), or [binary](/wiki/Binary_numeral_system "Binary numeral system") representations.

### Subnetting history

In the early stages of development of the Internet Protocol, the network number was always the highest order octet (most significant eight bits). Because this method allowed for only 256 networks, it soon proved inadequate as additional networks developed that were independent of the existing networks already designated by a network number. In 1981, the addressing specification was revised with the introduction of [classful network](/wiki/Classful_network "Classful network") architecture.[[2]](#cite_note-rfc791-2)

Classful network design allowed for a larger number of individual network assignments and fine-grained subnetwork design. The first three bits of the most significant octet of an IP address were defined as the _class_ of the address. Three classes (_A_, _B_, and _C_) were defined for universal [unicast](/wiki/Unicast "Unicast") addressing. Depending on the class derived, the network identification was based on octet boundary segments of the entire address. Each class used successively additional octets in the network identifier, thus reducing the possible number of hosts in the higher order classes (_B_ and _C_). The following table gives an overview of this now obsolete system.

Classful network design served its purpose in the startup stage of the Internet, but it lacked [scalability](/wiki/Scalability "Scalability") in the face of the rapid expansion of networking in the 1990s. The class system of the address space was replaced with [Classless Inter-Domain Routing](/wiki/Classless_Inter-Domain_Routing "Classless Inter-Domain Routing") (CIDR) in 1993\. CIDR is based on variable-length subnet masking (VLSM) to allow allocation and routing based on arbitrary-length prefixes. Today, remnants of classful network concepts function only in a limited scope as the default configuration parameters of some network software and hardware components (e.g. netmask), and in the technical jargon used in network administrators' discussions.

### Private addresses

Early network design, when global end-to-end connectivity was envisioned for communications with all Internet hosts, intended that IP addresses be globally unique. However, it was found that this was not always necessary as private networks developed and public address space needed to be conserved.

Computers not connected to the Internet, such as factory machines that communicate only with each other via [TCP/IP](/wiki/TCP/IP "TCP/IP"), need not have globally unique IP addresses. Today, such private networks are widely used and typically connect to the Internet with [network address translation](/wiki/Network_address_translation "Network address translation") (NAT), when needed.

Three non-overlapping ranges of IPv4 addresses for private networks are reserved.[[8]](#cite_note-rfc1918-8) These addresses are not routed on the Internet and thus their use need not be coordinated with an IP address registry. Any user may use any of the reserved blocks. Typically, a network administrator will divide a block into subnets; for example, many [home routers](/wiki/Residential_gateway "Residential gateway") automatically use a default address range of _192.168.0.0_ through _192.168.0.255_ (_192.168.0.0/24_).


## IPv6 addresses

Main article: [IPv6 address](/wiki/IPv6_address "IPv6 address")



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Ipv6_address.svg/300px-Ipv6_address.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Ipv6_address.svg)



[](/wiki/File:Ipv6_address.svg "Enlarge")

Decomposition of an IPv6 address from [hexadecimal](/wiki/Hexadecimal "Hexadecimal") representation to its binary value.





In IPv6, the address size was increased from 32 bits in IPv4 to 128 bits, thus providing up to 2128 (approximately 3.403×1038) addresses. This is deemed sufficient for the foreseeable future.

The intent of the new design was not to provide just a sufficient quantity of addresses, but also redesign routing in the Internet by allowing more efficient aggregation of subnetwork routing prefixes. This resulted in slower growth of [routing tables](/wiki/Routing_table "Routing table") in routers. The smallest possible individual allocation is a subnet for 264 hosts, which is the square of the size of the entire IPv4 Internet. At these levels, actual address utilization ratios will be small on any IPv6 network segment. The new design also provides the opportunity to separate the addressing infrastructure of a network segment, i.e. the local administration of the segment's available space, from the addressing prefix used to route traffic to and from external networks. IPv6 has facilities that automatically change the routing prefix of entire networks, should the global connectivity or the [routing policy](/wiki/Routing_policy "Routing policy") change, without requiring internal redesign or manual renumbering.

The large number of IPv6 addresses allows large blocks to be assigned for specific purposes and, where appropriate, to be aggregated for efficient routing. With a large address space, there is no need to have complex address conservation methods as used in CIDR.

All modern desktop and enterprise server operating systems include native support for the [IPv6](/wiki/IPv6 "IPv6") protocol, but it is not yet widely deployed in other devices, such as residential networking routers, [voice over IP](/wiki/Voice_over_IP "Voice over IP") (VoIP) and multimedia equipment, and some [networking hardware](/wiki/Networking_hardware "Networking hardware").

### Private addresses

Just as IPv4 reserves addresses for private networks, blocks of addresses are set aside in IPv6\. In IPv6, these are referred to as [unique local addresses](/wiki/Unique_local_address "Unique local address") (ULAs). The routing prefix _fc00::/7_ is reserved for this block,[[9]](#cite_note-rfc4193-9) which is divided into two _/8_ blocks with different implied policies. The addresses include a 40-bit [pseudorandom](/wiki/Pseudorandomness "Pseudorandomness") number that minimizes the risk of address collisions if sites merge or packets are misrouted.

Early practices used a different block for this purpose (_fec0::_), dubbed site-local addresses.[[10]](#cite_note-rfc3513-10) However, the definition of what constituted a _site_ remained unclear and the poorly defined addressing policy created ambiguities for routing. This address type was abandoned and must not be used in new systems.[[11]](#cite_note-rfc3879-11)

Addresses starting with _fe80::_, called [link-local addresses](/wiki/Link-local_address "Link-local address"), are assigned to interfaces for communication on the attached link. The addresses are automatically generated by the operating system for each network interface. This provides instant and automatic communication between all IPv6 hosts on a link. This feature is used in the lower layers of IPv6 network administration, such as for the [Neighbor Discovery Protocol](/wiki/Neighbor_Discovery_Protocol "Neighbor Discovery Protocol").

Private and link-local address prefixes may not be routed on the public Internet.

## IP address assignment

IP addresses are assigned to a host either dynamically as they join the network, or persistently by configuration of the host hardware or software. Persistent configuration is also known as using a **static IP address**. In contrast, when a computer's IP address is assigned each time it restarts, this is known as using a **dynamic IP address**.

Dynamic IP addresses are assigned by network using [Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol](/wiki/Dynamic_Host_Configuration_Protocol "Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol") (DHCP). DHCP is the most frequently used technology for assigning addresses. It avoids the administrative burden of assigning specific static addresses to each device on a network. It also allows devices to share the limited address space on a network if only some of them are online at a particular time. Typically, dynamic IP configuration is enabled by default in modern desktop operating systems.

The address assigned with DHCP is associated with a _lease_ and usually has an expiration period. If the lease is not renewed by the host before expiry, the address may be assigned to another device. Some DHCP implementations attempt to reassign the same IP address to a host, based on its [MAC address](/wiki/MAC_address "MAC address"), each time it joins the network. A network administrator may configure DHCP by allocating specific IP addresses based on MAC address.

DHCP is not the only technology used to assign IP addresses dynamically. [Bootstrap Protocol](/wiki/Bootstrap_Protocol "Bootstrap Protocol") is a similar protocol and predecessor to DHCP. [Dialup](/wiki/Dialup "Dialup") and some [broadband networks](/wiki/Broadband_networks "Broadband networks") use dynamic address features of the [Point-to-Point Protocol](/wiki/Point-to-Point_Protocol "Point-to-Point Protocol").

Computers and equipment used for the network infrastructure, such as routers and mail servers, are typically configured with static addressing.

In the absence or failure of static or dynamic address configurations, an operating system may assign a link-local address to a host using stateless address autoconfiguration.

### Sticky dynamic IP address

A _sticky dynamic IP address_ is an informal term used by cable and DSL Internet access subscribers to describe a dynamically assigned IP address that seldom changes. The addresses are usually assigned with DHCP. Since the modems are usually powered on for extended periods of time, the address leases are usually set to long periods and simply renewed. If a modem is turned off and powered up again before the next expiration of the address lease, it often receives the same IP address.

### Address autoconfiguration

Address block _169.254.0.0/16_ is defined for the special use in link-local addressing for IPv4 networks.[[12]](#cite_note-rfc6890-12) In IPv6, every interface, whether using static or dynamic address assignments, also receives a link-local address automatically in the block _fe80::/10_.[[12]](#cite_note-rfc6890-12) These addresses are only valid on the link, such as a local network segment or point-to-point connection, to which a host is connected. These addresses are not routable and, like private addresses, cannot be the source or destination of packets traversing the Internet.

When the link-local IPv4 address block was reserved, no standards existed for mechanisms of address autoconfiguration. Filling the void, [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft") developed a protocol called [Automatic Private IP Addressing](/wiki/Automatic_Private_IP_Addressing "Automatic Private IP Addressing") (APIPA), whose first public implementation appeared in [Windows 98](/wiki/Windows_98 "Windows 98").[[13]](#cite_note-13) APIPA has been deployed on millions of machines and became a [de facto standard](/wiki/De_facto_standard "De facto standard") in the industry. In May 2005, the [IETF](/wiki/IETF "IETF") defined a formal standard for it.[[14]](#cite_note-rfc3927-14)

### Addressing conflicts

An IP address conflict occurs when two devices on the same local physical or wireless network claim to have the same IP address. A second assignment of an address generally stops the IP functionality of one or both of the devices. Many modern [operating systems](/wiki/Operating_system "Operating system") notify the administrator of IP address conflicts.[[15]](#cite_note-15)[[16]](#cite_note-16) When IP addresses are assigned by multiple people and systems with differing methods, any of them may be at fault.[[17]](#cite_note-17)[[18]](#cite_note-18)[[19]](#cite_note-19)[[20]](#cite_note-20)[[21]](#cite_note-21) If one of the devices involved in the conflict is the [default gateway](/wiki/Default_gateway "Default gateway") access beyond the LAN for all devices on the LAN, all devices may be impaired.

## Routing

IP addresses are classified into several classes of operational characteristics: unicast, multicast, anycast and broadcast addressing.

### Unicast addressing

The most common concept of an IP address is in [unicast](/wiki/Unicast "Unicast") addressing, available in both IPv4 and IPv6\. It normally refers to a single sender or a single receiver, and can be used for both sending and receiving. Usually, a unicast address is associated with a single device or host, but a device or host may have more than one unicast address. Sending the same data to multiple unicast addresses requires the sender to send all the data many times over, once for each recipient.

### Broadcast addressing

[Broadcasting](/wiki/Broadcasting_(computing) "Broadcasting (computing)") is an addressing technique available in IPv4 to address data to all possible destinations on a network in one transmission operation as an _all-hosts broadcast_. All receivers capture the network packet. The address _255.255.255.255_ is used for network broadcast. In addition, a more limited directed broadcast uses the all-ones host address with the network prefix. For example, the destination address used for directed broadcast to devices on the network _192.0.2.0/24_ is _192.0.2.255_.

IPv6 does not implement broadcast addressing and replaces it with multicast to the specially defined all-nodes multicast address.

### Multicast addressing

A [multicast address](/wiki/Multicast_address "Multicast address") is associated with a group of interested receivers. In IPv4, addresses _224.0.0.0_ through _239.255.255.255_ (the former [Class D](/wiki/Classful_network "Classful network") addresses) are designated as multicast addresses.[[22]](#cite_note-rfc5771-22) IPv6 uses the address block with the prefix _ff00::/8_ for multicast. In either case, the sender sends a single [datagram](/wiki/Datagram "Datagram") from its unicast address to the multicast group address and the intermediary routers take care of making copies and sending them to all interested receivers (those that have joined the corresponding multicast group).

### Anycast addressing

Like broadcast and multicast, [anycast](/wiki/Anycast "Anycast") is a one-to-many routing topology. However, the data stream is not transmitted to all receivers, just the one which the router decides is closest in the network. Anycast addressing is a built-in feature of IPv6.[[23]](#cite_note-23)[[24]](#cite_note-24) In IPv4, anycast addressing is implemented with [Border Gateway Protocol](/wiki/Border_Gateway_Protocol "Border Gateway Protocol") using the shortest-path [metric](/wiki/Metrics_(networking) "Metrics (networking)") to choose destinations. Anycast methods are useful for global [load balancing](/wiki/Load_balancing_(computing) "Load balancing (computing)") and are commonly used in distributed [DNS](/wiki/Domain_name_system "Domain name system") systems.

## Geolocation


[![[icon]](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg)



This section **needs expansion**. You can help by [adding to it](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=IP_address&action=edit§ion=). _(July 2020)_









A host may use [geolocation software](/wiki/Geolocation_software "Geolocation software") to deduce the [geographic position](/wiki/Geographic_position "Geographic position") of its communicating peer.[[25]](#cite_note-oreilly-25)

## Public address

A public IP address, in common parlance, is a globally routable unicast IP address, meaning that the address is not an address reserved for use in [private networks](/wiki/Private_network "Private network"), such as those reserved by [RFC](/wiki/RFC_(identifier) "RFC (identifier)") [1918](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1918), or the various IPv6 address formats of local scope or site-local scope, for example for link-local addressing. Public IP addresses may be used for communication between hosts on the global Internet.

## Firewalling

For security and privacy considerations, network administrators often desire to restrict public Internet traffic within their private networks. The source and destination IP addresses contained in the headers of each IP packet are a convenient means to discriminate traffic by [IP address blocking](/wiki/IP_address_blocking "IP address blocking") or by selectively tailoring responses to external requests to internal servers. This is achieved with [firewall](/wiki/Firewall_(computer) "Firewall (computer)") software running on the network's gateway router. A database of IP addresses of restricted and permissible traffic may be maintained in [blacklists](/wiki/Blacklist_(computing) "Blacklist (computing)") and [whitelists](/wiki/Whitelist "Whitelist"), respectively.

## Address translation

Multiple client devices can appear to share an IP address, either because they are part of a [shared web hosting service](/wiki/Shared_web_hosting_service "Shared web hosting service") environment or because an IPv4 [network address translator](/wiki/Network_address_translator "Network address translator") (NAT) or [proxy server](/wiki/Proxy_server "Proxy server") acts as an [intermediary](/wiki/Intermediary "Intermediary") agent on behalf of the client, in which case the real originating IP address is masked from the server receiving a request. A common practice is to have a NAT mask many devices in a private network. Only the public interface(s) of the NAT needs to have an Internet-routable address.[[26]](#cite_note-26)

The NAT device maps different IP addresses on the private network to different TCP or UDP [port numbers](/wiki/Port_number "Port number") on the public network. In residential networks, NAT functions are usually implemented in a [residential gateway](/wiki/Residential_gateway "Residential gateway"). In this scenario, the computers connected to the router have private IP addresses and the router has a public address on its external interface to communicate on the Internet. The internal computers appear to share one public IP address.

## Diagnostic tools

Computer operating systems provide various diagnostic tools to examine network interfaces and address configuration. [Microsoft Windows](/wiki/Microsoft_Windows "Microsoft Windows") provides the [command-line interface](/wiki/Command-line_interface "Command-line interface") tools [ipconfig](/wiki/Ipconfig "Ipconfig") and [netsh](/wiki/Netsh "Netsh") and users of [Unix-like](/wiki/Unix-like "Unix-like") systems may use [ifconfig](/wiki/Ifconfig "Ifconfig"), [netstat](/wiki/Netstat "Netstat"), [route](/wiki/Route_(command) "Route (command)"), lanstat, [fstat](/wiki/Fstat_(Unix) "Fstat (Unix)"), and [iproute2](/wiki/Iproute2 "Iproute2") utilities to accomplish the task.

description: An Internet Protocol address (IP address) is a numerical label assigned to each device connected to a computer network

title: Regional Internet registry
content:
Organization responsible for managing network numbering

[![Crystal Clear app linneighborhood.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Crystal_Clear_app_linneighborhood.svg/16px-Crystal_Clear_app_linneighborhood.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Crystal_Clear_app_linneighborhood.svg) [Internet portal](/wiki/Portal:Internet "Portal:Internet")


A **regional Internet registry** (**RIR**) is an organization that manages the allocation and registration of [Internet number](/wiki/Internet_number "Internet number") resources within a region of the world. Internet number resources include [IP addresses](/wiki/IP_address "IP address") and [autonomous system (AS)](/wiki/Autonomous_system_(Internet) "Autonomous system (Internet)") numbers.



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Regional_Internet_Registries_world_map.svg/310px-Regional_Internet_Registries_world_map.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Regional_Internet_Registries_world_map.svg)



[](/wiki/File:Regional_Internet_Registries_world_map.svg "Enlarge")

Map of regional Internet registries





The regional Internet registry system evolved over time, eventually dividing the responsibility for management to a registry for each of five regions of the world. The regional Internet registries are informally liaised through the unincorporated **Number Resource Organization** (NRO), which is a coordinating body to act on matters of global importance.[[1]](#cite_note-1)





## Contents



*   [1 Five regional registries](#Five_regional_registries)
*   [2 Internet Assigned Numbers Authority](#Internet_Assigned_Numbers_Authority)
*   [3 Number Resource Organization](#Number_Resource_Organization)
*   [4 Local Internet registry](#Local_Internet_registry)
*   [5 See also](#See_also)
*   [6 References](#References)



## Five regional registries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Regional_Internet_registry&action=edit§ion=1 "Edit section: Five regional registries")]

The [African Network Information Center](/wiki/AFRINIC "AFRINIC") (AFRINIC) serves [Africa](/wiki/Africa "Africa").[[2]](#cite_note-afrinic-2) The [American Registry for Internet Numbers](/wiki/American_Registry_for_Internet_Numbers "American Registry for Internet Numbers") (ARIN) serves [Antarctica](/wiki/Antarctica "Antarctica"), [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada"), parts of the [Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean "Caribbean"), and the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States").[[3]](#cite_note-arin-3) The [Asia-Pacific Network Information Centre](/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Network_Information_Centre "Asia-Pacific Network Information Centre") (APNIC) serves [East Asia](/wiki/East_Asia "East Asia"), [Oceania](/wiki/Oceania "Oceania"), [South Asia](/wiki/South_Asia "South Asia"), and [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia "Southeast Asia").[[4]](#cite_note-apnic-4) The [Latin America and Caribbean Network Information Centre](/wiki/Latin_America_and_Caribbean_Network_Information_Centre "Latin America and Caribbean Network Information Centre") (LACNIC) serves most of the [Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean "Caribbean") and all of [Latin America](/wiki/Latin_America "Latin America").[[5]](#cite_note-lacnic-5) The [Réseaux IP Européens Network Coordination Centre](/wiki/RIPE_NCC "RIPE NCC") (RIPE NCC) serves [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe"), [Central Asia](/wiki/Central_Asia "Central Asia"), [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia"), and [West Asia](/wiki/West_Asia "West Asia").[[6]](#cite_note-ripe-6)



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Regional_Internet_Registries_world_map_2002-2005.svg/230px-Regional_Internet_Registries_world_map_2002-2005.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Regional_Internet_Registries_world_map_2002-2005.svg)



[](/wiki/File:Regional_Internet_Registries_world_map_2002-2005.svg "Enlarge")

Regional Internet registries 2002–2005







[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Regional_Internet_Registries_world_map_until_2002.svg/230px-Regional_Internet_Registries_world_map_until_2002.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Regional_Internet_Registries_world_map_until_2002.svg)



[](/wiki/File:Regional_Internet_Registries_world_map_until_2002.svg "Enlarge")

Regional Internet registries until 2002





## Internet Assigned Numbers Authority[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Regional_Internet_registry&action=edit§ion=2 "Edit section: Internet Assigned Numbers Authority")]

Regional Internet registries are components of the Internet Number Registry System, which is described in [IETF](/wiki/Internet_Engineering_Task_Force "Internet Engineering Task Force") [RFC](/wiki/RFC_(identifier) "RFC (identifier)") [7020](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7020).[[7]](#cite_note-7) The [Internet Assigned Numbers Authority](/wiki/Internet_Assigned_Numbers_Authority "Internet Assigned Numbers Authority") (IANA) delegates Internet resources to the RIRs who, in turn, follow their regional policies to delegate resources to their customers, which include [Internet service providers](/wiki/Internet_service_provider "Internet service provider") and end-user organizations. Collectively, the RIRs participate in the [Number Resource Organization](/wiki/Number_Resource_Organization "Number Resource Organization") (NRO),[[8]](#cite_note-nro-8) formed as a body to represent their collective interests, undertake joint activities, and coordinate their activities globally. The NRO has entered into an agreement with [ICANN](/wiki/Internet_Corporation_for_Assigned_Names_and_Numbers "Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers") for the establishment of the [Address Supporting Organisation](/wiki/Address_Supporting_Organisation "Address Supporting Organisation") (ASO),[[9]](#cite_note-aso-9) which undertakes coordination of global IP addressing policies within the ICANN framework.

## Number Resource Organization[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Regional_Internet_registry&action=edit§ion=3 "Edit section: Number Resource Organization")]

The **Number Resource Organization** (**NRO**) is an unincorporated organization uniting the five RIRs.[[8]](#cite_note-nro-8) It came into existence on October 24, 2003, when the four existing RIRs entered into a [memorandum of understanding](/wiki/Memorandum_of_understanding "Memorandum of understanding") (MoU) in order to undertake joint activities, including joint technical projects and policy coordination. The youngest RIR, [AFRINIC](/wiki/AFRINIC "AFRINIC"), joined in April 2005.

The NRO's main objectives are to:

*   Protect the unallocated [IP](/wiki/IP_address "IP address") number resource pool
*   Promote and protect the bottom-up policy development process of the [Internet](/wiki/Internet "Internet")
*   Serve as a focal point for the [Internet community](/wiki/Internet_community "Internet community") to provide input on the RIR system

## Local Internet registry[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Regional_Internet_registry&action=edit§ion=4 "Edit section: Local Internet registry")]

A **local Internet registry** (**LIR**) is an organization that has been allocated a block of [IP addresses](/wiki/IP_address "IP address") by a RIR, and that assigns most parts of this block to its own customers.[[10]](#cite_note-10) Most LIRs are [Internet service providers](/wiki/Internet_service_provider "Internet service provider"), enterprises, or academic institutions. Membership in a regional Internet registry is required to become a LIR.

## See also[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Regional_Internet_registry&action=edit§ion=5 "Edit section: See also")]

*   [Country code top-level domain](/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain "Country code top-level domain")
*   [Geolocation software](/wiki/Geolocation_software "Geolocation software")
*   [Internet governance](/wiki/Internet_governance "Internet governance")
*   [National Internet registry](/wiki/National_Internet_registry "National Internet registry")

[IETF](/wiki/Internet_Engineering_Task_Force "Internet Engineering Task Force"). [doi](/wiki/Doi_(identifier) "Doi (identifier)"):[10.17487/RFC7020](https://doi.org/10.17487%2FRFC7020). title: SignalR
content:
**SignalR** is a [free and open-source](/wiki/Free_and_open-source "Free and open-source") [software library](/wiki/Software_library "Software library") for [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft") [ASP.NET](/wiki/ASP.NET "ASP.NET") that allows server code to send asynchronous notifications to client-side [web applications](/wiki/Web_application "Web application"). The library includes server-side and client-side [JavaScript](/wiki/JavaScript "JavaScript") components.





## Contents



*   [1 Details](#Details)
*   [2 See also](#See_also)
*   [3 References](#References)
*   [4 Further reading](#Further_reading)
*   [5 External links](#External_links)



## Details[[edit](/w/index.php?title=SignalR&action=edit§ion=1 "Edit section: Details")]

ASP.NET SignalR is a library for [ASP.NET](/wiki/ASP.NET "ASP.NET") developers to add real-time web functionality to their applications. Real-time web functionality is the ability to have server-side code push content to the connected clients as it happens, in real-time.[[1]](#cite_note-1)

SignalR takes advantage of several transports, automatically selecting the best available transport given the client's and server's capabilities. SignalR takes advantage of [WebSocket](/wiki/WebSocket "WebSocket"), an [HTML5](/wiki/HTML5 "HTML5") API that enables bi-directional communication between the browser and server. SignalR will use WebSockets under the covers when it's available, and gracefully fall back to other techniques and technologies when it isn't, while the application code remains the same.[[2]](#cite_note-Mohl2012-2)[[3]](#cite_note-MackeyTulloch2012-3)

SignalR also provides a simple, high-level [API](/wiki/API "API") for doing server-to-client [RPC](/wiki/Remote_procedure_call "Remote procedure call") (call JavaScript functions in a client's browser from server-side .NET code) in an ASP.NET application, as well as adding useful hooks for connection management, such as connect/disconnect events, grouping connections, authorization.
